summary: Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was substituted in with only seven minutes left in their 0-0 draw against Burnley. Merson criticized Townsend on Twitter, referencing his earlier column where he questioned Townsend's place in the England squad. Despite Merson's initial skepticism, Townsend scored a crucial equalizer for England against Italy, prompting Merson to publicly admit his mistake and praise Townsend's goal. However, Merson couldn't resist another jab at Townsend following Tottenham's draw with Burnley, indicating that the rivalry between the two persists.

Chelsea has made a formal offer to acquire 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo, according to club president Naoki Ogane. Muto, who has been with FC Tokyo since 2013 and recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, would join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the transfer is completed. Despite Chelsea's Â£200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, Ogane asserts that this is unrelated to their interest in Muto. Muto, who has 11 international caps and one goal for Japan, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has three goals in four games this season. He expressed honor at the offer but has not yet decided to join Chelsea.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. Researchers suggest that antibiotics, similar to their use in farm animals, may contribute to weight gain in children. The study, published in the journal Pediatrics, indicates that these drugs could be a factor in the childhood obesity epidemic. In England, a third of 10-11 year olds and over a fifth of 4-5 year olds are overweight or obese. The Finnish study compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records, finding that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two. Children who received antibiotics as babies were more likely to be overweight, with repeated prescriptions before age two further increasing the odds. Boys showed a higher propensity for weight gain after antibiotic use and were slightly taller. The study did not prove causation but suggested that antibiotics may kill gut bacteria that normally consume some food, leaving more for the body and potentially increasing appetite. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, noting that increased antibiotic use could contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic. Previous research has also linked early antibiotic use to higher risks of eczema and digestive problems. There is growing concern about the over-prescription of antibiotics leading to antibiotic resistance and the emergence of superbugs.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, which was captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell, saw the guard lose his footing, slide sideways, and drop his rifle. Despite the embarrassment, the guard quickly stood up as his colleagues marched past unaffected. The fall is believed to be due to the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular daily event in the summer and every other day in the winter, attracting thousands of tourists. The Queen's Guard, though ceremonial, consists of fully operational soldiers.

A&E networks are remaking the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally drew over 100 million viewers. The new version, set to air in 2016, will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. It will focus on the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America, and his descendants. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce. The remake aims to be more authentic by drawing from Alex Haley's novel and consulting scholars. The new adaptation seeks to resonate with both original fans and a new generation, especially relevant given recent historical milestones and ongoing racial issues in the U.S.

Police are investigating allegations by former royal footman Christopher Lawler, who claims palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in January 1978. Lawler, then 27, recounted being pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day of work, leading him to leave the job immediately. His complaints were allegedly ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. The incident resurfaced when Lawler contacted palace officials again following inquiries into historical child sex abuse cover-ups. The palace has since pledged to cooperate with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping while driving, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the video, Melissa raps about their life in Happy Valley, Oregon, and the couple's journey to parenthood, including the moment she discovered she was pregnant. The video concludes with the couple sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. It took five takes to film the clip, and the couple expressed surprise at its viral success. The video was created to inform loved ones living far away about the baby. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt, featuring a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over time. It was worn in key scenes, including Scarlett's encounters with Rhett Butler. The dress was part of a larger collection of over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia amassed by James Tumblin, who bought the dress for $20 in the 1960s to prevent it from being discarded. Other notable items sold at the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The toddler, who fell approximately 10 to 12 feet, was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He suffered minor bumps, bruises, and a leg injury but was in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach the boy. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was temporarily closed following the incident.

A non-functional speed camera, previously enforcing a 30mph limit in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been angled towards a house's front door. The camera, part of 300 decommissioned due to outdated technology in 2013, has not worked for over two years. Birmingham City Council is aware and will send an engineer to assess and potentially remove the camera. There are no plans to include this camera in a new pilot using digital technology. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete as part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his happiness and readiness to participate, emphasizing his commitment to making Jamaica proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability and anticipated exciting performances. The full Jamaican team for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their commitment to Barcelona by attending a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid. Accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella, they watched Barcelona secure an 85-80 victory, though Real Madrid remained top of their division by points difference. Prior to this, Neymar had helped Brazil defeat Chile 1-0, enduring tough challenges during the match. Barcelona, under Luis Enrique, had previously won a La Liga El Clasico, leading the league by four points. Neymar and his team are set to face Celta Vigo in their next La Liga match as they aim for a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrant arrivals from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 migrants rescued by the Italian coast guard from Friday to Monday. Save the Children reported fears of 400 missing migrants after a ship carrying 550 people capsized, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. There has been an increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is uncertain about why Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool but is pleased with the decision. Sanchez, who had options from several elite clubs, opted for Arsenal and has made a significant impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been related to negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities and adaptability. Ahead of a Premier League match, Wenger downplays rumors of a potential move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers' management of Liverpool following the sale of Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis, will be challenged by Wiggins, who aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career, views the Hour Record as a significant challenge in cycling history. The event will be held at the Lee Valley VeloPark, with tickets available from April 19 and the event broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins hopes to inspire others to challenge themselves with their own cycling endeavors.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion and current World No. 1, described her challenging victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as a significant 'eye-opener' as the claycourt season begins. Williams won the match 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, improving her career record against Errani to 8-0, but expressed dissatisfaction with her performance. The U.S. team was defeated 3-2 overall, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in relegation to World Group II. Williams acknowledged she is not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought and needs to adapt her playing style. Despite her 19th singles grand slam win at the Australian Open, the French Open has been her least successful major. The U.S. captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, emphasized the need for harder work to return to the elite group next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Despite Falcao's struggles at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season, River Plate vice president Matias Patanian expressed the club's desire for Falcao to return, stating "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao has recently shown good form for Colombia, scoring three times in two games to tie the nation's all-time goalscoring record. The deal is complicated, with Falcao currently on a season-long loan from Monaco, and it is uncertain whether Manchester United will exercise their option to keep him.

In 2015, Ella Henderson, a former X Factor finalist and pop star known for her impressive vocals and long hair, became the official face of Batiste dry shampoo's 'Ready For It' campaign. This marked her first brand collaboration. The campaign featured Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city background, including a wavy style and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership was arranged by the MILES agency, and the international campaign launched with a TV advertisement featuring Henderson's single "Mirror Man." Ella expressed excitement about working with Batiste, a brand she regularly uses. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and Batiste, anticipating an exciting 2015.

In Kenosha, Wisconsin, family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres on March 14, are shocked and upset by a billboard erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association featuring Torres and his dog. The billboard, which reads "Thank you for your support, Kenosha," has been deemed disrespectful by Siler's loved ones, who believe it glorifies the officer responsible for Siler's death. Torres is currently on leave pending the investigation into the shooting. The police association claims the billboard was intended to thank the community for its support and not to offend. Siler, who was wanted on a felony warrant, was shot after arming himself during a confrontation with Torres. This incident followed another shooting by Torres ten days prior, where he wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while the shooting of Knight was deemed justified by the District Attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces in Negur, southeastern Iran. The militants, reportedly from Pakistan, were associated with the group Jaish al Adal, which claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group from Balochistan, aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan and has targeted Shiites. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and is investigating, requesting evidence from Iran to apprehend any militants who may have fled into Pakistan.

In Japan, a political discussion about extraterrestrial threats has emerged, sparked by a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani informed Japan's parliament, the Diet, that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered any unidentified flying objects (UFOs) from outer space. Nakatani explained that while the ASDF scrambles fighter jets to investigate potential airspace violations, they have only found birds or other non-aircraft objects, not extraterrestrial UFOs. Inoki, known for his diverse career in wrestling, politics, and diplomacy, asked about the scrambling of aircraft for extraterrestrial threats and research into alien visitors. This isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed alien invasions; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal implications under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He avoided sitting on the seat due to cleanliness concerns. The toilet collapsed, causing severe injuries. He initially contacted his companions for help before being taken to a hospital where he received dozens of stitches. Jin later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid compensation, claiming he was sitting when the toilet broke. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which led to his identification. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation revealed that Rebbie had been sexually abusing the girl since she was nine years old and had been filming her and others using the hidden camera. Authorities found 41 videos from the camera, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims and is being held on a $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama has created a unique series of father-daughter portraits where fathers leap dramatically into the air next to their po-faced daughters, who smile directly at the camera. These images, part of Aoyama's latest book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," allow fathers to express their fun side by portraying them as 'heroes jumping the sky, enfold(ing) strong excitement and hope.' The fathers are dressed in sharp suits, contrasting with their daughters' casual clothing, and the photos are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks. Despite the energetic poses, some older fathers show pained expressions. The series has garnered significant online interest due to its curious nature, though details about its creation remain limited.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the subsequent focus on the start of the county championship season. Amidst this, Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England cricket team is highlighted. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, is seen in various emotional states during a Surrey team photo session at the KIA Oval, ahead of the new campaign. His return to Surrey aims to force his way back into the Test set-up, especially as England hopes to regain the Ashes on home soil this summer. The passage also notes Pietersen's interactions with photographers and teammates during the photo session, showcasing his jovial mood despite deep contemplation about his international future.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, facing relegation, dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, was initially fired due to poor performance but reinstated by owner Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Massone sacked him again, leaving Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January, is Ceahlaul's third coach this season and will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao regrets his unsuccessful loan move to Manchester United, despite his unhappiness in France. Falcao, a former Atletico Madrid striker, joined United on a season-long loan but has struggled to perform at his previous levels following a serious knee injury. Manchester United would need to pay Â£46 million to make the transfer permanent, but with only four goals scored this season, they are unlikely to exercise this option. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played more and participated in the Champions League, despite his discomfort in Monaco.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The incident occurred on Saturday when the offender demanded cash from the owner's daughter, subsequently stealing the till and approximately $1500 in cash. No weapons were reportedly used during the robbery. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice within a month for inappropriate relationships with underage students. Initially, she was arrested on March 19 for allowing a 15-year-old student to kiss her and touch her breasts, leading to her suspension and administrative leave. Subsequently, she was arrested again on March 24 after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. The second incident allegedly occurred in her car near another school in Dallas. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail both times and released after posting bail. The school district assured that appropriate actions were taken to prevent her from interacting with students.

A video showing a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws, has garnered over 500,000 views online. The dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, was seen being carried by the crocodile for hours. New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the incident while on holiday, noted that the crocodile did not move for a long time. The marina is near a sanctuary where crocodiles reside, and such sightings are common due to the urbanization bringing humans and crocodiles closer together. Social media reactions to the video were largely negative, with some users expressing horror and aversion towards crocodiles.

Steve Bruce remains confident in Hull City's ability to avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which leaves them just two points above the drop zone. Initially aiming for 10 wins to ensure survival, Bruce now hopes eight or nine wins will suffice. Hull performed well in the first half against Southampton but conceded a penalty by James Ward-Prowse and a late goal by Graziano Pelle. Bruce attributes Hull's struggles to long-term injuries to key players, though some, like Mohamed Diame and James Chester, have recently returned. Hull faces a challenging run-in with games against top teams like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Southampton's manager, Ronald Koeman, dealt with an internal issue when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty designated for Ward-Prowse, prompting Koeman to reinforce team rules.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the test had finished, leading to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results. Guffick also altered some pupils' answers himself. The local education authority investigated and found breaches of exam rules, resulting in the Department for Education invalidating the school's results. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted his conduct was unacceptable. Although he claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible, the panel ruled that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions. The panel chair noted Guffick's regret but emphasized that his behavior was inexcusable. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper who has had limited playing time, is happily married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. They tied the knot in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Lindegaard, who has been with Manchester United since 2010, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently the third-choice goalkeeper. Despite his struggles on the pitch, he enjoys a successful personal life with Beqiri, who regularly shares her modeling photos on Instagram.

The 13 glowing blue letters from the old Yankee Stadium, which were expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, failed to attract any bids at a Sotheby's auction. Only a Sotheby's employee bid $260,000 to start the bidding. The letters, purchased by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson after the stadium's final game in 2008, had been installed in 1976. Jackson hoped a new generation would own and enjoy the iconic signage. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after Sterling was seen inhaling nitrous oxide and both players were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players but decided not to discipline them, emphasizing the importance of understanding the responsibilities of being elite sportspersons. With Steven Gerrard available after a suspension, Rodgers' focus is on leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management, drawing on past close losses as part of the learning process.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, shared a photo on Twitter of himself relaxing with his dog at home in London after the international break. He performed well in Germany's 2-0 win against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who was signed from Real Madrid for Â£42.5 million in 2013, missed Arsenal's recent game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to play against Liverpool. Despite rumors of him being in a Berlin nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger denied these claims. Ozil has been in good form since returning from injury, contributing four assists and three goals. He feels he is adjusting well to English football, appreciating the frequent matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has affirmed that the club has no plans to replace current manager Luis Enrique, expressing that they are 'very happy' with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to securing the La Liga title with only six games remaining. Despite rumors suggesting Enrique might be replaced, Bartomeu refuted these claims, highlighting his satisfaction with Enrique's management. Bartomeu noted Enrique's hard work and preparation, particularly ahead of crucial matches, and emphasized that Barcelona remains competitive for three major trophies. Recently, Barcelona defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, showcasing their strong form under Enrique's leadership.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, providing a boost after their FA Cup semi-final defeat. The vice-captain, who had 14 months left on his current contract, is set to sign improved terms worth around Â£100,000 per week, extending his deal until 2020. Henderson, 24, is the third key player to commit to the club this season, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. His form has been excellent, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is considered a potential successor to Steven Gerrard as club captain. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume after the season, though he has rejected a new deal for now. Liverpool's Chief Executive, Ian Ayre, expects Sterling to remain at the club long-term.

Filipe Luis has expressed his desire to remain at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Luis, who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea after moving from Atletico Madrid, has faced challenges in securing the left back position at Stamford Bridge. Despite this, he asserts his happiness at Chelsea and his commitment to staying. Following his participation in Brazilâs friendly matches against France and Chile, Luis is now focused on the Premier League title race. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is emphasizing the importance of maintaining focus and winning every game, as the team faces a challenging series of matches in the league.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. Initially suspended for being 'reckless' when his knee collided with North's head during a try, Hughes was shown a red card but this has now been rescinded. Despite no intent, Hughes faced further sanction at the original hearing. The ban was overturned following an appeal by Wasps, amid fierce criticism. North, who was left unconscious and had to be stretchered off, has been advised to take a month off due to concussion symptoms. The incident, which occurred on March 27, led to Hughes missing Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon. The appeal panel concluded that the incident was accidental and not foul play.

A fiery sunset in Washington, photographed by Seattle native Tim Durkan, was caused by wildfires in Siberia. These fires, started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control due to strong winds, destroying villages. The smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, including parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunsets are due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors (greens, blues, yellows, purples), allowing red and orange to penetrate the air unfiltered. This effect is more pronounced during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the reddish hue of the sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig, a St. Louis, Missouri resident, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. After a month, police found and returned the car with new red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook, calling her car "pimpin." She is now having the car professionally cleaned due to strong cigarette and marijuana smells. Schoenig is also creating a special smoothie, the Sexton on Wheels, at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, who located her car and notified the police.

Manchester City players, including stars like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, face losing Â£500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. These incentivized contracts are designed to help the club adhere to financial fairplay rules. Currently in fourth place, Manchester City's chances of securing a Champions League spot are uncertain, especially after a recent loss to Manchester United. The top three Premier League finishers automatically qualify for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. In total, the City squad has approximately Â£12 million in bonuses contingent on reaching their European target. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's decline in performance, which includes seven losses and early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. The team's failure to secure a top-four finish could also impact their ability to attract top-class players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba.

In a 'mini-derby' between Manchester United and Manchester City Under 18s, United won 1-0 with a goal from Callum Gribbin, who scored a delightful free-kick. The match, held at Altrincham's Moss Lane, featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were from Manchester. The game was free to attend, attracting nearly 1,000 spectators. United's victory puts them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City, affected by injuries, have lost both their matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The match showcased promising talent from both sides, highlighting the potential for homegrown players to progress to the first team.

Joe Hart, England's goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who received his 50th cap for England, expressed admiration for Buffon's continued excellence at 37 years old. Hart sees Buffon as an inspiration and aims to continue improving and accumulating more caps for his country.

Chipotle has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver burritos to customers in 67 cities. This move follows Chipotle's previous rejections of third-party delivery services. The partnership will include a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Postmates operates by hiring independent contractors who use their own vehicles, similar to Uber. Chipotle's decision to enter the delivery market coincides with high-profile visits from presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other franchises, including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring or have launched delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have made a plea to remove the death penalty as a sentencing option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the 2013 bombings. In an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard detailed the profound impact the tragedy has had on their family, including the loss of their 8-year-old son and severe injuries to their daughter, Jane. They advocate for Tsarnaev to spend the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release, instead of facing the death penalty, to avoid prolonged appeals and further emotional trauma. The sentencing phase is set to begin and is expected to last four weeks.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747 that has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire. The conversion, which took three years and cost approximately Â£400 million, includes multiple bedrooms, lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, and a conference room. The jet, originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, now accommodates a single owner and dozens of guests. The interior features hotel-like amenities, including a master bedroom, an office, and a lounge with a television. The plane also has an aeroloft on the top deck with eight full beds and a state room at the back. The luxurious conversion is depicted in artist's impressions by Greenpoint Technologies.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. The mission successfully delivered over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker. However, the attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge failed as the rocket tipped over upon landing. This was SpaceX's second attempt at such a landing, with the previous attempt in January resulting in an explosion. SpaceX aims to reduce space access costs by reusing rockets, similar to airplanes. The Dragon will remain at the space station for five weeks before returning to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and other items. This marks SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS and the second attempt for this specific mission, after the first was postponed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the inaugural wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located within the Westgate Hotel. She collaborated with NBC's Today show to create a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win an 'ultimate wedding'. The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will marry on April 23. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Notably, Priscilla emphasized that no Elvis impersonators will be allowed. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, Tennessee, and couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation to enter the contest.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equaling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Despite a tough season, Henderson is optimistic about Liverpool's chances, especially after recent wins following poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Liverpool is currently four points behind Manchester City. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored in the match, with Allen's goal being his first at Anfield. Newcastle had a potential penalty claim denied when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, crucial for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute following a counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves in the second half. Roma moved four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches. Security was heightened due to past incidents, but no problems were reported. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho.

This season, Doncaster Rovers have struggled with an uninspired campaign, placing them in mid-table mediocrity in League One. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town, whose play-off hopes had diminished, resulted in a dull 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The lack of action made it challenging for Doncaster's media team to compile match highlights, leading them to create a very short 27-second video with only 14 seconds of actual match footage, featuring the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux interacts with his blood parrot cichlid by stroking and massaging it with his hand inside the tank. The fish, initially shy, eventually relaxes and enjoys the interaction, often returning to be stroked again. Giroux began this practice after noticing the fish becoming more sociable when fed by hand, following the removal of two other fish that were bullying it. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid bred in Taiwan around 1986, shows signs of frustration if not played with daily. Giroux spends at least 15 minutes each day interacting with the fish.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character, returned to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs, including breaking his wrist by punching a locker in frustration. His aggression and natural exuberance are valued by the team, but they require careful management. After a clash with Marlon Samuels, England coach Peter Moores had a significant conversation with Stokes, which seemed to positively influence his behavior. England aims to nurture Stokes' potential while ensuring his aggression is channeled effectively for the team's benefit, focusing on achieving runs and wickets. The team prefers to have Stokes and Chris Jordan play as much as possible to help them reach their full potential, despite occasional considerations of playing a second spinner like Adil Rashid.

The Euro 2016 qualifier between Wales and Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are top contenders in Group B, with Wales having a chance to qualify for a major tournament for the first time since 1958. Belgium leads the group on goal difference despite both teams having 11 points from five games. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has heightened expectations for qualifying. The Football Association of Wales reported overwhelming demand for tickets. Despite speculation about playing at the larger Millennium Stadium, the match will remain at the Cardiff City Stadium due to UEFA rules and player preference.

England's Under-17 squad, led by coach John Peacock, has been announced for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions, defending champions, qualified with a perfect record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their campaign starts against Italy on May 7 in Burgas. Notable inclusions are Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (first-time call-up), and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold (recalled after missing the Elite Round). The squad features talented players from various Premier League clubs. Matches are scheduled against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth program. Other clubs like Arsenal and Barcelona are also interested in him. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 due to his family's preference for him to continue his studies. Manchester City has engaged in discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a compensation package. Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure Patoulidis as part of building for the future.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a Â£400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and is due to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death. Santillan, who worked in London, Paris, and Miami, was pronounced dead at the scene with injuries to her head and neck. Police are committed to solving the case and are particularly interested in speaking to anyone who saw her on the Friday or Saturday before her death.

Dawn, a woman who has experienced seven miscarriages, expressed her distress on The Jeremy Kyle show after discovering that a family friend, Jamie, had stolen Â£207 intended for her babies' gravestone. Jamie, a convicted burglar who lives with Dawn and her partner (also named Jamie), initially denied the accusation but was proven guilty by a lie detector test conducted on the show. The stolen money was part of savings for a Â£500 gravestone for one of Dawn's miscarried babies, Daniel James. Dawn expressed feelings of betrayal and sadness, emphasizing the importance of the gravestone as a symbol of love for her child. After the revelation, she burst into tears and left the stage, later being comforted by her partner.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a persecuted minority group in northern Iraq, with most being women, children, ill, or elderly. The release was coordinated with Arab tribal leaders and received by Peshmerga forces, who transported them to Irbil. The exact number of released Yazidis varies between 217 and 228. This follows previous releases of Yazidis by ISIS since their attack last year, which displaced hundreds of thousands and led to reports of massacres, rape, and enslavement. An international coalition, including the U.S., responded with airstrikes against ISIS. The Yazidis, a pre-Islamic sect, are of Kurdish descent and have faced long-standing persecution.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham and England striker, has had a remarkable season marked by his animated celebrations on the pitch and now features in a clever new animation off it. Nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards, Kane's season highlights include his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle and notable strikes against Chelsea and Arsenal. The animation, produced by Copa90, uses still photographs to create an animated effect showcasing his best goals and celebrations. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', is released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead Liverpool forward despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, speaking after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work, defended Rodgers, stating that the team's future shouldn't be determined by one game. He noted the difficulty of integrating new players and expressed hope that Rodgers, the players, and the staff will aim to win a trophy and return to the top four next season. Carragher emphasized the importance of making the right signings to improve the team. Additionally, Carragher discussed his community work through his 23 Foundation, aiming to help underprivileged youth in Merseyside.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to it being deemed a security risk. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was in his hand luggage for a flight to Lanzarote. Security officers, described as 'over-zealous' by James's father, Phil, frisked the boy and demanded the toy be handed over after it was detected by X-ray machines. Phil criticized the security checks as 'ludicrous' but complied to avoid missing their flight. Upon returning from their holiday, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and explained that their actions were in accordance with government-set security regulations, which prohibit items resembling prohibited items, including replica or model guns.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, known as 'Rich,' posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The ad lists specific requirements for the ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, skilled with their hands, a good cook, and great in bed. The successful candidate would receive benefits such as a gym membership, a phone of their choice, and potential access to a company car, phone, and laptop. Rich describes himself as a 31-year-old, athletic, white man with tattoos, brown hair and eyes, who doesn't drink, smoke, or do drugs. He enjoys traveling, the outdoors, sports, fishing, and camping, and owns properties, making a good income. He emphasizes that he is willing to spend money on his partner and will consider all reasonable offers, though former partners need not apply.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has received support from five former England managersâGraham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClarenâfor his proposal to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. Dyke's plan also seeks to redefine 'home-grown' as players who have trained in England for three years before the age of 18, rather than 21. Despite opposition from the Premier League, the former managers warn that rejecting these changes could hinder England's progress in international competitions and prolong the wait for a World Cup win. They emphasize the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level as a significant disadvantage and highlight the emergence of young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane as evidence of England's potential to produce top talent, provided they are given opportunities to play.

In the latest episode of the show, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby daughter, much to the joy of her husband, Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner. Despite Ross initially marrying Demelza out of duty, his affection for her is evident as he expresses that she makes him a better man. However, the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is criticized for its rapid progression from announcement to birth within a short span of episodes, similar to a previous pregnancy storyline involving another character, Elizabeth. Fans have humorously noted the accelerated pregnancy timelines on social media.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to maintain focus on their own performance and ignore the results of their relegation rivals as they fight to stay in the Premier League. The Foxes, currently at the bottom of the table but just three points from safety, have gained a survival lifeline with back-to-back wins, including a crucial 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Pearson emphasized that their future is in their own hands and stressed the importance of not getting overly optimistic despite the improved situation. He highlighted that while favorable results from other games help, the team must concentrate on winning their own matches to secure their Premier League status.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's migration included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale rather than an endangered western gray whale. This discovery could impact the understanding of gray whale populations and their genetic differentiation.

Residents on Hokkaido Island's east coast experienced an unexpected change when 1,000ft of seabed emerged overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu. This land, now up to 50ft above sea level, is believed to have risen due to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The emergence, measuring roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, surprised locals who reported no sounds or tremors. Authorities do not expect further expansion and believe it is unrelated to recent earthquakes. Marine organisms remain attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has refuted rumors of his departure from Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, expressing his deep affection for the club. Despite a recent conflict with manager Laurent Blanc, who benched him for a Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel maintains his contentment in Paris and has no intention of leaving the Ligue 1 team. He emphasized his happiness at PSG, his love for the club, the city, and his teammates, and his desire to sign a new contract. However, PSG's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could influence Van der Wiel's future with the club.

Carlos Tevez has been instructed to terminate his contract with Juventus to facilitate a return to his former club, Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus not expiring until the end of the next season, Tevez has expressed his desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old, but club president Daniel Angelici emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. Tevez, who joined Boca's youth academy in 1996 and scored 26 league goals in 76 appearances before moving to Corinthians in 2005, is on course to win a second Serie A title with Juventus and has a chance at European glory. Juventus, though reluctant to lose their top scorer (Tevez has netted 17 times this season), have accepted his wish to leave and are identifying potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that any move would not affect Tevez's position in the Argentina national team, emphasizing that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are great teams.

During Bayern Munich's 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League, manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his trousers, revealing his underwear. Despite this, Bayern secured a place in the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Porto, who had a two-goal lead from the first leg, were overpowered by Bayern's performance.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. The crash involved three vehicles. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries and chest pain, respectively. A 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also airlifted with arm injuries and abdominal pain. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. One person was trapped and required hydraulic cutting gear to be freed. The highway was closed with diversions in place.

This weekend, Arsenal, currently second in the Premier League, will host top-placed Chelsea. Arsenal's Mesut Ozil, excited for the match, received an Apple Watch as a gift, which he showcased on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. Ozil is expected to start for Arsenal, who trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games left. Arsenal has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere from injury, with Ray Parlour highlighting Wilshere's potential if he can maintain fitness.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford on Sunday. Despite controversy and accusations of favoring Manchester United, Clattenburg has sent off only two players this season, both from United (Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw). City's captain, Vincent Kompany, is suspended for the match after being sent off by Clattenburg during an international game. The derby is crucial as United, on a five-game winning streak, are a point above City, with both teams vying for second place behind Chelsea. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of viewing MP Billy Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string," sparking controversy. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, made this claim on his party's website, suggesting the government expected Gordon to resign following accusations of domestic violence and the revelation of his criminal past. Gordon, who quit the Queensland Labor Party and announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, has thrown the government into chaos due to their slim majority. Katter defended his statement, explaining his use of the term "black puppet" was influenced by his own experiences with racism. His comments have drawn criticism on social media.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and stares, she aims to show that she is similar to everyone else, just doing things a bit differently. Her videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," seek to entertain and inspire, turning negativity into positivity. Dayna, who was once told she might never walk, now dances, drives, and attends college. She has also started motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, an MLS side with a significant Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has had a challenging loan spell at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a Mexico international, is also attracting interest from eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for approximately Â£8 million. Additionally, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has rejected their initial offer and is being courted by several European clubs including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

Early Saturday morning, a gang of at least three people set a white Dodge Charger on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles after an argument with the driver, who was pumping gas. The incident occurred around 12:15am, with two passengers inside the car at the time. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, who fled, leading to the group spraying gasoline on the car and igniting it. No injuries were reported, but the car was severely damaged. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being utilized in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a southern Iowa chiropractor, surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting his misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these charges, Manuel received outstanding patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires him to prove that the circumstances leading to the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can practice again. These circumstances included bartering sex for services and recommending patients stop taking prescribed medication. Manuel's practice was located in a residential area in Lamoni, and he has not worked at his former practice for some time.

The United States has lodged a complaint with Moscow following an incident where a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea. The Pentagon stated that the U.S. plane was in international airspace north of Poland when the Russian jet performed aggressive maneuvers at high speed in close proximity. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying towards its border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denied. The Pentagon and State Department plan to file a diplomatic petition with Russia. This is not the first such incident; a similar dangerous encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, secured with padlocks and chains in a hard rifle case inside a truck safe, was stolen from the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The thief is believed to have broken the rear right passenger-side window, used a rope to pull the rifle case out, and possibly employed another vehicle to create momentum. The window frame was pulled from the door, and the rifle case's handle was broken off. The agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing were also stolen. Officers found skid marks, pieces of rope, and the broken handle near the car. The stolen items, except the rifle, were found at a nearby Residence Inn. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was notified of the theft prior to Obama's visit, but it is unclear if security measures were increased.

In 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, was accused of brutally murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in the dining room of his home in Red Hill, Canberra. The alleged crime involved stomping on Freebody's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. A jury heard that Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and testified that there was evidence of Costa's declining mental state both before and during the incident. Professor Mullen noted that Costa's erratic behavior, including fluctuating moods and a trail of faeces leading from the crime scene to the toilet, indicated a confused mental state. The prosecution argued that Costa may have feigned memory issues during his examination, but Professor Mullen denied this. The case hinges on whether Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven, as this could result in a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines' superior penalty record (15 goals from 16 attempts). Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but the miss did not cost Everton as Kevin Mirallas scored the winning goal. Martinez emphasized that Barkley had the right to take the penalty and praised his responsibility in doing so, while Baines was supportive of the decision.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, appearing to be a case of murder-suicide. The ship, operated by Holland America Line, had departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin door. Holland America Line is cooperating fully with the ongoing investigation.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao in World Cup qualifying as their coach. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament by drawing 2-2 in a second-leg match against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in Willemstad. Charlton Vicento, a former Holland Under 21 international, scored a crucial goal in the 87th minute to secure the draw. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has a personal connection to Curacao through his mother, has experience as a World Cup semi-finalist both as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014 under Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, a seasoned player with numerous major European trophies, considers keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being at the bottom of the table with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances of survival. He views this challenge as his primary objective for the season. Cambiasso, who has had an illustrious career at Inter Milan and Real Madrid, joined Leicester in the summer on a one-year deal and has become a key player. He expresses happiness with his current situation in the East Midlands and is focused on securing more points to help Leicester avoid relegation.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her two children under five due to her refusal to stop drinking, partying, and using legal highs like MKat. Gemma handed her children over to her mother, Debbie, when they were four months old. Debbie, who has been caring for the children, is threatening to ban Gemma from seeing them because of her behavior and suspected theft. Debbie claims Gemma stole an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle, though Gemma admits to stealing money and items from her mother in the past. Debbie, who appeared with Gemma on The Jeremy Kyle Show, is considering banning Gemma from her home and from seeing the children due to lack of trust.

In the match between Chelsea and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Eden Hazard scored the opening goal for Chelsea, giving them a 1-0 lead. The goal came after a strong challenge from Chelsea captain John Terry on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, which led to a loose ball. Cesc Fabregas collected the ball and passed it to Oscar, who then sent it to Hazard for the goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed during half-time analysis that Terry's challenge on Falcao should have resulted in a foul, with Souness describing it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry and Redknapp also criticizing the tackle.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway after a rear tire blowout, but all occupantsâScott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driverâwere safely evacuated. Michael Barnett captured and shared video of the incident on CNN iReport. Scott posted photos of the charred bus on Instagram, noting that only her Bible was spared in the back lounge. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy for powering homes, with initial trials in Scotland showing success. These lasers, which will orbit Earth and use mirrors to harvest sunlight, aim to make solar power viable in regions like Scotland and provide instant power restoration in disaster-hit areas. Unlike science fiction depictions, these lasers won't be powerful enough to be used as weapons. Separately, Tokyo researchers proposed a laser system for the ISS to clear space debris, which also wouldn't be weaponizable. Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about satellite control.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offences against children, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who has a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, was last seen leaving the hospital at 6.15pm on Tuesday. He is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He also admitted to ten offences related to possessing indecent images of children. Authorities have launched a manhunt and urge anyone with information on his whereabouts to come forward urgently, given his learning difficulties and the nature of his offences.

V. Stiviano, former companion of Donald Sterling, has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to return over $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling sued her. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men, claiming Donald Sterling used their money to buy her luxury items including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with receiving gifts from Donald Sterling and denied taking advantage of him. The court decision was celebrated by Shelly Sterling, with her attorney stating it sets a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of ill-begotten gifts. Donald Sterling's racist remarks, including objections to Stiviano associating with African-Americans, led to his NBA ban, fine, and loss of ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four key playersâa goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and top-quality strikerâto have a chance at winning the Premier League. He specifically questioned whether Olivier Giroud, despite his 14 league goals this season, is capable of leading Arsenal to the title. Henry compared Arsenal's needs to Chelsea's successful acquisitions of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa, which helped Chelsea win the league. Arsenal currently sits third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who remained unnamed, expressed fear for her future relationships and questioned why she was targeted. She revealed that she only spoke out after learning Van Ryn had been caught and has since attempted suicide. Van Ryn sat calmly in the dock without looking at the victim during her testimony. The young woman also mentioned her ongoing struggles with depression since age 14, including hospitalizations for self-harm and suicide attempts. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, the 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering well from a serious knee injury that has kept him out for over a year. He last played for the first team in March 2014 during a Champions League match against Bayern Munich. Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21 team in a 1-0 loss to Reading, marking his second full match in a week. He expressed feeling "better and better" and is looking forward to his next game, indicating he is close to returning to the first team.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, accidentally fell to his death from a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, after running from a taxi driver to avoid paying the fare. Phillips and his friends had taken a taxi home from a night out in Cardiff but lacked sufficient cash to pay. They planned to use an ATM but instead fled when the taxi stopped. Phillips ran into the dark, leapt over a fence, and fell down the cliff. His body was found the next day by a dog walker. The coroner recorded an accidental death verdict, noting Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the danger ahead. Phillips, a University of Birmingham accountancy graduate, worked for Pretty Green, a clothing label by Oasis star Liam Gallagher.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, despite the passport agency making a Â£42 million profit during the chaos. Managers at the agency received bonuses up to Â£3,500. Ministers refused to provide a blanket refund to affected families, some of whom paid extra for expedited services or missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April last year and January this year, totaling Â£203,066 with an average payout of Â£92.68. The Passport Office could not disclose how many claims were rejected due to a system failure in their customer complaint database. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, called for compensation but was astonished by the low number of approvals. The agency made a surplus of Â£42.3 million between April and October last year, and managers received a total of Â£1.8 million in bonuses in 2013-14, with an average reward of Â£499 and the highest being Â£3,500.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, preserved with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars, is up for sale. The semi-detached property, untouched for over 80 years, includes the original bathroom and kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. Notable features are the mint green and black bathroom, stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, and original tins of produce like Cadburyâs Marvel dried milk. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the house retains its antique charm with a guide price of Â£200,000 to Â£250,000. It will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol, potentially appealing to antique enthusiasts or families.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter mid-2012 season after Smith's concussion. Kaepernick remained the starter for the rest of the season, leading the 49ers to their first Super Bowl since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
The passage states that "Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film. It was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent her early life there, and later moved to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 within the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, offering access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network. It is owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, specifically under the NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises unit.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, formed Blur with Graham Coxon at Stanway School. Blur's debut album, Leisure, released in 1991, received mixed reviews. Influenced by various genres, the band achieved worldwide success with their self-titled album in 2001. Albarn's solo debut, Everyday Robots, released on 28 April 2014, was co-produced by Richard Russell and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, along with samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is home to many important national institutions.

The passage states that "Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails. It is featured on their debut extended play (EP), titled "Broken," which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage discusses two adaptations of the character Bob Lee Swagger. In the 2007 film "Shooter," Mark Wahlberg portrays Swagger, a Force Recon veteran who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. In the TV series "Shooter," Ryan Phillippe plays Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action upon discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House (also known as House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, starting from November 16, 2004, and concluding on May 21, 2012.

It debuted at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, marking Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States. The album sold 757,000 copies and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, titled Stadium Arcadium. This album marked the last time guitarist John Frusciante would feature with the band, as he confirmed his departure in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is a controversial yet influential figure in British history, with ongoing debates about her policies.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Besides his musical career, he is also a writer, having contributed weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, is known not only for his acting roles but also for his work in narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially ValÃ¨ncia, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain, following Madrid and Barcelona. It has approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center. Valencia is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain, with its capital being the city of Valencia.
Buffy Summers is a character who was first portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film. Subsequently, Sarah Michelle Gellar took on the role in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, which was announced as the final season on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary field within computational linguistics that creates technologies for computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It integrates knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of SR include voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing, call routing, controlling smart home devices, searching for spoken words in podcasts, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control via Direct Voice Input. The field has seen significant advancements, particularly through the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, who have publicized their use of deep learning in their SR systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 â January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970, initially known as the Golden State Comic Book Convention. Alf served as its chairman starting in 1970. The convention was founded by a group including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and later became known as the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

In the Turkish Open, France's Victor Dubuisson and South Africa's Jaco van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland, a four-time major winner, is one stroke behind at 15 under par, alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy, who recently recovered from an ankle injury, shot a third consecutive 67, featuring an eagle on the 12th hole. Despite some setbacks, including three-putting on the third and tenth holes, he rallied with birdies and an eagle. McIlroy aims for a third Race to Dubai title and leads England's Danny Willett by a significant margin. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland are fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's main opposition party al-Wefaq, emphasized the necessity for the government to demonstrate a willingness to offer concrete solutions for meaningful national dialogue. He called for a representative from the royal family to engage in dialogue, highlighting Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist figure. Hardliners within the government, led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, oppose dialogue, fearing it will embolden opposition demands. Despite this, Sheikh Salman welcomed dialogue and believed it was essential, even though many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties. He advocated for working with reformists within the royal family, including the Crown Prince, who had previously agreed to a seven-point plan towards a constitutional monarchy before it was disrupted by GCC troops. Sheikh Salman expressed hope for more assertive US policy under Secretary of State John Kerry and criticized the UK government for its lack of public pressure on Bahrain to end violence and human rights abuses. He reiterated al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations and called for the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and human rights activists.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for later. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it globally for about 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. Colleagues and friends remember him for his generosity, academic prowess, and commitment to historically informed music.

In the year ending March, 57 homicides were recorded in Scotland, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. This represents a significant drop from nine years ago. Only one homicide case from 2015-16 remained unresolved by March 31, 2016. Sharp instruments, predominantly knives, were the most common method, accounting for 51% of homicides. Approximately 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts to reduce violent crime and support at-risk communities. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against over-optimism, noting past revisions of homicide figures and the rise in sexual and violent crimes.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking the first Premier League defeat for the Black Cats this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but they were unable to equalize despite creating numerous chances.
