Netanyahu responded by summoning ambassadors, recalling Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The postponement aims to mitigate conflict amid Kerry's expected vision for ending the conflict and addressing critiques of the Obama administration by the Israeli government. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas views the resolution as paving the way for a forthcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday. A commemorative stamp featuring the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and Alexandra Gardens to mark her birthday. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, expressed their well-wishes. Prince William addressed recent criticisms of his commitment to royal duties, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own path. Ten stamps were released for the Queen's birthday, and on her actual birthday, she will unveil The Queen's Walkway and light a beacon. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle. Republic, a republican pressure group, criticized the BBC's coverage of the Queen's birthday as not being fair, balanced, and proportionate.

In the EFL Cup match, West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored quick goals before halftime, giving West Ham control. Cheltenham had chances but couldn't convert, with Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header being notable attempts. West Ham made seven changes after recent losses, while Cheltenham remained unchanged. The match saw several attempts and fouls from both sides, but West Ham's defense held firm, with goalkeeper Adrian largely untested. Cheltenham's exit marked the end of League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to see him while turning his VW Transporter. Werner, a father-of-four, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not seek jail time for Werner, considering it a momentary lapse. Werner expressed remorse and could not explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, attempted to return to the UK after fighting in Syria under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani. He was a prominent member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was known for his online presence, often masked, posting videos and images from the conflict. Khawaja faces up to life imprisonment for his activities, which included appeals for donations and propaganda efforts aimed at recruiting British Muslims. He was arrested upon his return to the UK after faking his own death and attempting to re-enter unnoticed. Khawaja admitted to four offenses, and his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja was considered highly dangerous and was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at Belmarsh prison.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth in the table. He has turned down a contract offer from Wrexham and is now Barnsley's third signing for next season. Barnsley is preparing for their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom highlighted Jackson's pace and ability to challenge defenders, stating he will fit well with their playing style.

Numerous bottles, believed to be from a lost container overboard during stormy weather, have washed up at Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall. The National Trust and volunteers are clearing the bottles, which pose a risk to wildlife. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there is no definitive evidence linking the bottles to the lost container from the MV Blue Ocean. Cornwall Wildlife Trust expresses concern about the impact on marine life. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

The incident took place on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in several people sustaining minor injuries. The road was subsequently closed, with diversions established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland has confirmed that investigations into the incident are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, contributing to Bolton Wanderers' second-place finish in League One and their subsequent promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has accumulated 83 appearances across all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson noted Dervite's significant contribution towards the end of the campaign despite being somewhat overlooked earlier. Dervite has now signed a new contract with Bolton, following in the footsteps of David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, who also renewed their contracts post-promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything," while Labour's Baroness Smith accused the Lib Dems of giving people "false hope." Previously, the two parties had cooperated to defeat the government on issues related to EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, this cooperation ended when MPs rejected those amendments, with Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source called the Lib Dems' actions "fairly obvious grandstanding" aimed at campaign content. Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite past alliances on various issues, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and doubted future collaborative events. Both parties' leaderships are expected to maintain a business-like relationship.

In this election, defense is a low priority for most political parties, ranking just within the top 10 concerns of the electorate, far behind issues like the economy, the NHS, and immigration. UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya have contributed to public combat fatigue and political reticence on the subject. Despite global instability and threats, the UK has been reducing its armed forces, with the Army shrinking from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy having only 19 warships, and the RAF with eight front-line fast jet squadrons. The UK has fallen to sixth place in global defense spending and is projected to drop below the NATO threshold of 2% GDP spending on defense. Only UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party commit to maintaining this goal. The UK's nuclear deterrent, Trident, is under scrutiny, with parties differing on its renewal and operational details. The upcoming operational aircraft carriers, Queen Elizabeth and Prince of Wales, face challenges in manning and equipment, highlighting the risk of a "hollow force." Overall, the UK's defense capabilities are under strain, with potential further cuts looming despite political commitments to certain defense elements.

Barcelona, the Spanish football champions, have made an additional tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential interpretations of their fiscal obligations in the signing of Neymar. The club maintains that they did not commit any offense and that the original tax payment was in line with their obligations. Neymar's total cost to the club, including various fees and wages, amounts to Â£106.8 million. The payment follows accusations that the actual cost of the player was higher than initially disclosed. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is under investigation, though he denies any wrongdoing. A Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, died in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for retired individuals, emphasizing the need for safety measures. Age UK stresses the importance of older people maintaining their driving abilities for independence. Luciw, described as generous and kind-hearted, was a new father looking forward to his daughter's milestones. His brother, Simon, and mother, Andrea Shelton, mourn his loss and call for changes to prevent similar incidents. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must self-assess every three years without a medical or driving test. The DVLA states there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age, noting that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK's Caroline Abrahams highlights the significance of driving for older people's independence.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse, following reports of debilitating side effects experienced by many women. Two patients resigned from the original review group in protest over a perceived watered-down report. Independent expert Professor Alison Britton will now examine the final report's process and identify future lessons. The report recommended against routinely offering the procedures to women with pelvic organ prolapse, advocating for a range of treatments and informed patient choices, and mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an outright ban, the health secretary confirmed the recommendations would be implemented, noting the government lacked the power to ban the procedures, which is under the purview of the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite panel members around the report's conclusions. Some panel members and affected women criticized the report, leading to resignations and public outcry. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone mesh implant surgery in the past 20 years, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5,000m indoor record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan expressed excitement about her record being broken but initially raised concerns about the race's criteria for record ratification, including the absence of other competitors and potential drug testing. British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official despite these concerns. McColgan praised Muir's potential to win world medals and noted similarities between Muir's and her own record-breaking races. Muir previously broke her own British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won the event aboard Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who contracted an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite a strong performance in the final show-jumping phase. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, was competing just 10 months after a serious fall that required an induced coma. His medal chances were hindered by a poor performance in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also invites readers to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks, provides a guide to getting into equestrian, and encourages subscription to the BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, won his match against Fabio Fognini, the 29th seed, in four sets (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5) after two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini had opportunities to force a fifth set but Murray won five consecutive games to secure his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will next face Frenchman Benoit Paire. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week of the tournament with a win over Maria Sakkari. Murray described the match as tense and up and down, noting that he didn't play his best tennis at times but was pleased to finish in four sets. Fognini showed both talent and temperamental behavior, coming close to forcing a fifth set, which would have required a change in conditions due to fading light. Murray managed to overcome a deficit in the fourth set, saving set points in three consecutive games to level at 5-5 and eventually win the match.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts indicated alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, beyond licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The court heard that licensing laws were not strictly followed, and the bar had been operating improperly. O'Neill, with an "appalling record," was fined Â£3,000, and Thomas was fined Â£1,000.

During the launch of the Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto, Mike Nesbitt emphasized the importance of partnership over domination and expressed a preference for forming a government with the SDLP over Sinn FÃ©in. His comments sparked controversy, particularly after senior party colleague Danny Kennedy distanced himself from Nesbitt's remarks. Despite this, Nesbitt stood by his statements, highlighting community support and focusing on post-election scenarios. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' addresses various issues including healthcare, police numbers, infrastructure, LGBT rights, and Brexit impacts. Nesbitt framed the election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, criticizing incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced a motion to be approved by the assembly, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales by introducing automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, both posthumously and for living individuals. This initiative, referred to as 'Turing's Law' after Alan Turing, aims to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men. The motion has secured executive agreement and will be considered by the assembly to expedite the pardon process.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a race behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12, setting a new Scottish record and placing her second on the British all-time list. This achievement surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60 and trails only Zola Budd's British record of 4:17.57. Muir, who holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed her satisfaction with the result, especially as it was her first race of the season over this distance. She aims to secure a place in the Great Britain Olympics team for Rio through the British trials in Birmingham. Muir, who balances her athletic career with veterinary studies, started her season with an 800m victory in France and is set to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm.
The passage mentions that there are pictures available from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as "most excellent" for their water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi likely had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, suggesting the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot due to ample reasons for wishing him harm or death. UK officials believe the suspects poisoned Litvinenko with polonium-210 in London in 2006, though they deny wrongdoing. Horwell noted that the use of polonium indicates Russian state involvement but did not implicate President Vladimir Putin directly. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticisms of Putin were cited as possible motives. The public risk from polonium radiation in London remains uncertain, and Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death. The suspects left a trail of polonium and failed to provide a credible answer to the scientific evidence. Extradition attempts have failed, and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of Australia's Test team following Michael Clarke's retirement. Smith will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Smith has previously captained the Test side in three matches against India. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, is seen as a matured and important senior figure in the team. Both Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test, starting on 20 August.

Earlier this week, Mr. Farron declined to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin but expressed strong support for LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage, stating it would be a top priority. He also advocated for extending marital rights to transgender individuals, criticizing the spousal veto in current laws. Mr. Farron clarified his liberal stance on equality, despite voting against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about individual liberties, though he did not specify those concerns. He affirmed his support for equal legal access for all people regardless of sexuality.

In 2015, Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare has now taken over the plant for its pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. A spokesman expressed confidence in the "extremely positive" impact of the investment on the area. Councillor Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council, praised the announcement as fantastic news for Newcastle and the North East, highlighting its role in strengthening the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical player, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving on Friday as his contract ends. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, attributes these departures to the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff and anticipates more departures in the near future. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for the trio's dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, crashed at this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. Initially, he told MCN he was quitting road racing, but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing but has no plans to race on Hondas this year. Martin did not participate in the North West 200 after his teammate crashed in practice and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and felt he was essentially a test rider. After further testing, he informed his team the bike wouldn't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. Martin expressed interest in racing classics and other types of races instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential poll last month, saw significant losses in key northern states and Adamawa, but retained control of Rivers State. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with most northern states and Lagos going to the APC. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could impact oil revenue under President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections, though marred by violence in some areas, were generally more peaceful than previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under new leadership after 16 years in power, facing allegations of corruption and failure to address the Boko Haram insurgency.

The passage discusses allegations made by US-based environmental lobby group Mighty against Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of ignoring unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to haze in Singapore and Malaysia, caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. Olam and Temasek deny these allegations. Olam claims to have a strict sourcing policy against burning and deforestation, and it recently disclosed the names of its 14 suppliers after resisting earlier calls. Mighty's report suggests that Olam's practices could link Singapore's state fund to the annual haze affecting several Southeast Asian countries. The palm oil industry globally faces accusations of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and illegal burning. The report also raises concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of bulldozing rainforests for palm oil plantations, a claim Olam denies, stating its operations in Gabon are responsible and transparent.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started serving "puppy platters" following the introduction of a new law that permitted dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they were outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee issue and has only played from the bench in the last two games. Derby County's David Nugent may return after missing the recent draw with Huddersfield due to a groin injury. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring a late equalizer against the Terriers as a substitute.

The ban on YouTube in Pakistan has been lifted as Google has launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to open access to YouTube. The ministry of information technology stated that Google has provided a process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material, which YouTube will restrict after review. However, YouTube clarified that government requests for content removal are not automatically granted and are subject to community guidelines. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." Google has also launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing calls to withdraw from the upcoming presidential election due to his shared Swiss-Italian nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, boss of the Liberian Football Association, has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations which bars committee members with conflicts of interest. Scala previously withdrew from the 2015 elections for similar reasons when Sepp Blatter, also Swiss, was a candidate. However, Scala's spokesman argues that there is no conflict of interest this time as Blatter is not the incumbent president. The election to replace Blatter will occur in 18 days, with five candidates vying for the position.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed the following day. A forensic search was conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported "significant progress" in forensic inquiries and witness statements, suggesting a flashover explosion due to toxic fumes and ignition caused the incident. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with its inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 Nations Cup, but avoided disqualification after apologizing. Morocco, initially banned from the 2017 AFCON qualifying draw, was allowed to participate after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned Caf's ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 AFCON, citing Ebola fears, and was fined $50,000 after Cas reduced the original $1 million fine. Tunisia's dispute with Caf arose from a contentious penalty awarded during their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 AFCON, which Tunisia lost. Despite initial tensions, Tunisia's Football Federation (FTF) clarified they did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption, only criticizing the referee's appointment. Following mediation, Tunisia was confirmed to participate in the 2017 AFCON, facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco was drawn in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

In the 95th minute of a game at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas occurred during which Chelsea won 3-1. Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for violent conduct and Fernandinho a three-match ban following a scuffle with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford by an innings and 93 runs, leveling the four-match series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, achieving their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with his contributions in the field. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, and coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's hard work and improvement. Former players Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott commended England's overall performance, while Vaughan predicted a tight series. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the team's disappointment and emphasized the need for hard work to regain confidence.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley in his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales, having done so previously in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde for the summer tour. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips expects to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions' selection panel, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, viewing 2017 as a significant opportunity for Welsh coaches and rugby.

In a dramatic turn of events, Hull City, despite losing two strikers to injuries in the first half, managed to turn the game around in the second half. Robert Snodgrass, who came on as a substitute, scored and assisted in a quick two-goal burst that shifted the momentum. Hull's goalkeeper, David Marshall, made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas performed a remarkable goalline clearance in the dying moments to secure a 2-1 victory over Southampton. This win ended Hull's six-game losing streak but they remained in the bottom three. Southampton, fresh from a Europa League win, struggled to maintain their early lead and faced difficulties in concentration after their European exertions.

A motorcyclist, who lived locally, was killed in a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia canceled an investigation into claims of government abuse of power, citing the need to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This decision was condemned by the opposition and EU officials. The country has been in turmoil since covert recordings were released in 2015, allegedly showing ministers involved in vote-rigging and cover-ups. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev called the move illegal and urged protests, which led to a gathering outside the prosecutor's office. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn criticized the action, stating it was not in line with the rule of law and could jeopardize Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. The crisis began with recordings accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and revealing high-level corruption, which the government denies, accusing Zaev of attempting to destabilize the nation.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the top choice. Curtis emphasizes the need for a manager who can help the team avoid relegation, noting the increased difficulty of the Championship and the challenges of returning to the Premier League. Swansea's rise from near bankruptcy to a well-established Premier League club is highlighted, along with the belief that the team has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis asserts that the current squad has the potential to stay in the Premier League and stresses the importance of the club's history to new signings.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 loss to Leyton Orient, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring the winning goal. The Daggers, who reached League One in 2010, needed a victory to maintain their slim survival hopes. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona initially gave Dagenham hope after Jay Simpson put Orient ahead 2-0. Dagenham, under manager John Still, have the worst goal difference in League Two and have conceded 20 more goals this season compared to last. Still, who returned for his third spell in December, is committed to helping the club gain promotion next season. Leyton Orient, now under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler, are two points behind the play-off spots. Hessenthaler emphasized the importance of professionalism and winning games to reach the play-offs, despite the challenges of losing two managers this season.

The passage details the return of former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, aged 36, to his former club as a youth coach starting in February. This marks his first job since retiring as a player. Liverpool manager JÃ¼rgen Klopp expressed enthusiasm about Gerrard's appointment, highlighting it as "wonderful news" and noting Gerrard's aspiration to become a manager in the future. Klopp emphasized the importance of understanding Gerrard's career goals and his readiness to learn the managerial role, combining his playing experience with new knowledge. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and left for LA Galaxy in 2015, retired in November after a 19-year career. He had been considered for the manager's position at MK Dons but deemed it premature. Gerrard is also pursuing his Uefa A coaching licence, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.

McManus scored early to give Morton the lead, followed by a goal from Forbes. McAusland's goal brought Alloa back into the game before halftime. However, additional goals from McManus and Johnstone secured a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in squalid conditions in three now-closed locations in Birmingham. Illegal school operators could face up to 51 weeks in jail. Ministers are considering increased regulation for places teaching more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed shock at the conditions found and suggested these cases may be the "tip of the iceberg," with concerns over child abuse or radicalization. Eighteen unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated, with three in Birmingham closed and their owners under investigation. Any place teaching children over 20 hours a week must register as a school. Some part-time education centers operate legally, but concerns exist about others exploiting home education laws to run illegal schools. Sir Michael criticized the education secretary's officials for providing confusing advice. The government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, emphasizing that the crackdown will apply to all religious groups. The education secretary intends to pursue prosecutions against identified unregistered schools, with a government consultation on further regulation ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, is poised to become the Scottish Borders' first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the exciting potential for the region to achieve distilling excellence. The gin production, though on a smaller scale with one of the UK's smallest stills, emphasizes local flavor and terroir from the Teviot valley. John Henderson of Born in the Borders praises the distillery's alignment with local sourcing ethos and its historical significance as the first new distillery in nearly 200 years. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor, symbolizing the landscape and the strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green, who was more than two times the legal driving limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds. Green, who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident, was prosecuted under health and safety legislation and jailed for 16 months and two weeks. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed that the family has been profoundly affected and emphasized the dangers of drunk driving. The Health and Safety Executive described Green's behavior as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker, can now train and play in friendly matches following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Barcelona confirmed he will join the first team's training session on Friday and be publicly presented as a new player on Monday at Camp Nou. Suarez can participate in football-related activities but is still banned from organized matches, including serving the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. His competitive debut for Barcelona is expected on October 26 against Real Madrid. Suarez can play in Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. Cas ruled that Fifa's suspension from all football-related activity was excessive, allowing Suarez to train and participate in promotional activities. Suarez's legal team argued that Fifa misapplied its rules and the sanction was disproportionate.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race by defeating Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene from Lithuania. The competition involved a 380-metre course with obstacles such as haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Participants included various combinations of carriers and carried individuals, not limited to married couples. Rich and Anna prepared by running around an athletics track for a week. They will compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond announced that job roles at the DVLA will change when the paper system for car tax discs is replaced by an electronic system in October 2014. He assured that there would be no job losses, instead, employees would be redeployed to other growth areas. This response was welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who said it would "give comfort" to DVLA employees. The new system will allow car tax to be paid via monthly direct debit, eliminating the need for physical tax discs.

The passage discusses Hungary's resistance to EU interference in its domestic policies, particularly regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education. Hungary's Foreign Minister, Mr. Szijjarto, asserts that these laws are within national competence and should not be interfered with by European institutions. He confirms that Hungary will not backtrack on these laws and has secured a veto promise from Poland against any EU sanctions. The EU is critical of Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, as well as a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University (CEU), founded by George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws. The EU has warned of potential action if Hungary does not make positive changes.

The upcoming live-action adaptation of the classic Disney film features an ensemble cast including Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Emma Thompson will voice Mrs. Potts, and Kevin Kline will play Maurice. Directed by Bill Condon, the film is set to release on 17 March 2017 and will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist for the Sunday Times known for his distinctive style and controversial opinions, passed away suddenly despite battling cancer. Diagnosed with multiple types of cancer, Gill remained positive and continued writing until his death. His final column, reflecting on his illness, will be published posthumously. Colleagues and industry figures have paid tribute to Gill, highlighting his exceptional writing, wit, and compassion. Gill, who overcame dyslexia, had a storied career marked by both acclaim and controversy. He was engaged to Nicola Formby at the time of his death and had children from previous relationships, including with former Home Secretary Amber Rudd.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator by a Russian diplomatic officer. Reports indicate he was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in a 10-day coma and serious brain injury. Sukhbaatar wore a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol with historical significance in Mongolia predating its association with Nazism. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, describing local press reports as "distorted." The suspect has not been identified or arrested, though the police clarified that this is not due to diplomatic immunity. Sukhbaatar's lawyer and family deny claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion on Monday, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. They are set to appear in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, prompting the Metropolitan Police to announce a review of airport security.

In the cricket match, Glamorgan's total was significantly contributed by Nick Selman's 101 runs, his second first-class century, after a period of low scores. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets for Gloucestershire in challenging conditions. Gloucestershire faced difficulties as Glamorgan's bowlers dominated. Aneurin Donald scored a quick 36 runs, and Glamorgan managed a bonus point thanks to Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten. Gloucestershire aimed for survival in their innings, ending the day in a balanced position. Glamorgan is led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph due to a neck issue. Both Selman and Taylor expressed satisfaction with their performances, with Selman hoping for continued success and Taylor noting the challenging conditions for bowlers.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after communicating with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Concerns arose over a planned murder attempt involving an ambush of police officers based on a false report of a non-existent crime. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and is awaiting sentencing. He confessed to planning to make a false police report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he intended to shoot them. These threats were made while he was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded Hughes in custody, noting his previous conviction for firearm possession in 2009. Hughes's legal team argued he did not intend to kill himself and would not have carried out the threat. North Wales Police were especially concerned as Hughes was on bail for firearms offences, though he was later cleared of those charges. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling for individuals in distress.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 19 runs in a crucial match. Surrey scored 255-7, with notable performances from Davies (90) and Ben Foakes (90), who shared a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire's chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, including key wickets of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan's 68 was not enough as Yorkshire were all out for 236. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised the team's collective effort, while Yorkshire's Alex Lees expressed disappointment despite a strong season in white-ball cricket.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced water ingress that the onboard pump could not handle. The crew contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. Holyhead coastguards responded by sending an RNLI lifeboat, which provided an additional pump and towed the trawler to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her final year veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May, which conflict with the April event. Despite finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, Muir is disappointed but focused on completing her degree. She expresses confidence in the Scotland team's performance and her own future Olympic potential. Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a possible target, despite her busy schedule with studies.

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's current struggles, attributing their distance from last season's title challenge to the loss of key players like Luis Suarez and the underperformance of new signings. He critiques manager Brendan Rodgers' transfer decisions and the team's lack of intensity and work-rate compared to the previous season. Savage also highlights Liverpool's defensive issues and the need for improvement to secure a top-four finish. Regarding the upcoming match against Chelsea, he predicts a tough game for Liverpool, suggesting a lineup that includes Kolo Toure over Dejan Lovren. Despite Liverpool's challenges, Savage believes Steven Gerrard can still contribute significantly to the team's future, emphasizing the mental and physical battles Gerrard faces as he ages.

A Â£45m educational facility will be constructed at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, featuring primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed delight in preserving McIlvanney's name, highlighting the writer's passion for good education. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," transitioned from an English teacher to a full-time writer, authoring acclaimed works like the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. He also made significant contributions as a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and through his political and sporting columns and TV programs. McIlvanney passed away on 5 December at his Glasgow home.

An area near the town's swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to the discovery of a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents nearby were advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls, and avoid going outside. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea, affecting three streets and causing disruption to ferry services. The evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger to the community. The mine's condition made it uncertain how much explosive material it contained, leading to the decision to move it to a safer location before disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their cooperation during the evacuation procedures.

UK Sport has cut funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, despite badminton winning a bronze medal at Rio 2016. Cycling's funding was reduced by over Â£4m. A total of Â£345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, Â£2m less than the Rio allocation. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Tokyo 2020. Badminton England's CEO expressed shock at the funding removal, calling it "incomprehensible" and a "catastrophic impact." Judo, which also won a bronze, saw a slight funding increase. UK Sport emphasized the need to prioritize investments to protect medal potential. Basketball, handball, and volleyball criticized UK Sport for not funding team sports, despite a review suggesting otherwise. Funding for new Olympic and Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. Despite strong objections from English Heritage and 49 residents, councillors voted 7-3 in favor, citing tourism benefits and improved living conditions for older residents. The new development will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments across a nine-storey and a seven-storey building. The council received 246 letters of support and objections from the Ancient Monuments Society, which argued the historic character of the area would be harmed.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely during a night out in Brecon. Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted of being the "hardest man in Brecon," punched and beat Boyd outside a bar, leading to his death. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Boyd's body was found unconscious by police in the early hours of 8 May. The community and Boyd's family expressed shock and grief, describing Boyd as full of life and promising, while Vallely's actions were condemned as despicable.

Andrew Travers left Barnet Council by mutual agreement following an error that led to voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched. Travers expressed his belief in the borough's continued growth and transformation. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. On election day, only a few voters were registered at one station, prompting the council to apologize and offer emergency proxy votes. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the issues. The council's review, concluding by the end of May, will assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

In a match between Gateshead and Wrexham, Josh Gillies scored a fine free-kick to put Gateshead ahead, but Wrexham equalized before half-time with a set-piece by Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman secured a win for Gateshead with a header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised Wrexham's performance and acknowledged his team's improvement in the second half. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, noting his team's decline in the second half and missed opportunities. The final score was Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 across 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan ranks lowest, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project, in collaboration with Airbus, aims to create a global broadband network using a constellation of at least 600, potentially up to 2,000, low-cost satellites. This initiative seeks to provide internet access to every school worldwide. To achieve this, Airbus is adopting new, high-volume, low-cost manufacturing methods, similar to those used in automotive and aerospace industries, producing three satellites per shift for under a million dollars each. The first assembly line has been established in Toulouse, France, with plans for additional lines in Florida. The project requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing, involving new automation and a scaled supply chain. The first satellites are scheduled for launch in April next year, with a rapid launch cadence planned thereafter. The constellation will be deployed using over 20 Soyuz rockets, with the goal of having nearly 300 satellites in orbit by the end of 2020, over 600 by 2021, and more than 800 by the mid-2020s. OneWeb faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing, but believes it has a first-mover advantage. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional financing. OneWeb, registered in the UK's Channel Islands, must comply with UK Space Agency regulations, particularly regarding debris mitigation. The constellation aims to de-orbit old satellites within two years to prevent space debris accumulation.

The passage discusses the impact of the UK government's recent spending review on Scottish public expenditure. Mr. Swinney, a Scottish government official, claims that the review places "unprecedented pressure" on public spending in Scotland and that the discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He criticizes the UK government's austerity measures, stating that more than Â£1bn of cuts are still to come by the end of the decade. Despite this, the UK government asserts that Scottish ministers will have Â£390m more in spending available next year, rising to Â£750m if underspend is included. Mr. Swinney emphasizes the Scottish government's commitment to protecting key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. In response, a UK government spokesman suggests that the Scottish government should focus on utilizing its new powers effectively. Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget and criticizes the Scottish government's self-congratulatory approach.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities and their families due to the lack of suitable accessible toilets, particularly Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced facilities. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers, are advocating for these to be made compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities. The passage emphasizes the psychological and practical impact on families when suitable facilities are unavailable, often leading to feelings of isolation and exclusion. Recommendations for Changing Places toilets have been in place since 2009, but they are not compulsory, leading to inconsistent implementation. The passage also mentions positive examples, such as Arsenal Football Club, which has installed a Changing Places toilet and received positive feedback. The overall call is for mandatory inclusion of these facilities in building regulations to ensure accessibility for all.

Italian consumers' organisations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's responded by stating that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, a strategy they claim has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and several European unions are supporting the complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate. The complaint also claims that franchisees are locked into longer-than-average contracts and pay above-market rates for leased premises, leading to higher prices and reduced consumer choice. The European Commission will review the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed credible. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, contributing $9.27 billion in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign with the hashtag #prayforjosh was initiated to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, after he was unexpectedly diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign, started by Bangor Elim Church where Josh's father works, quickly went viral, garnering global support. A massive billboard with the hashtag appeared in Holywood, funded by an anonymous donor. The campaign has seen significant engagement on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, with updates shared by the church and supported by Josh's classmates and people worldwide.

The passage discusses the proposed closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Wales that has been operational since 1805. Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, citing the barracks' long-standing service and its importance to the local community, which faces high unemployment. Davies plans to launch a petition against the decision and is concerned about the potential impact on the town's military tourism industry. The closure is part of a broader reorganisation of UK military buildings, which includes the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan and the eventual closure of Cawdor Barracks and a storage depot at Sennybridge. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports the restructuring but expresses concern about the uncertainty it creates for those affected.

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that while the industry, which contributes minimally to GDP and employs few people, may be a low priority for the government, it must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is seen negatively by the UK fishing industry, which hopes Brexit will allow them to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns of risks and trade-offs, such as potential increased access for EU boats to UK waters in exchange for continued market access for UK fish exports. The report also suggests retaining elements of the CFP post-Brexit and maintaining scientific-based quotas. There is concern about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in the UK post-Brexit. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit may bring, particularly in light of recent CFP quota increases favorable to the UK.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has extensive access to individual communications, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The NSA reportedly has "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple, though these companies deny involvement. The NSA's Director claims these operations help secure Americans, but details are undisclosed. Data protection laws vary by country, often regulating company data handling rather than government activity. User data is frequently stored in the US, subject to US jurisdiction and the Patriot Act, which allows easy access to non-US citizen data. UK Foreign Secretary William Hague neither confirmed nor denied British involvement in Prism. The EU Justice Commission expressed concern and sought more details from the US. Privacy International warns that the Prism program confirms their fears about global privacy violations.

The passage discusses the launch of Open AI, a research venture backed by prominent figures and companies including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The organization aims to develop artificial intelligence (AI) with a focus on ensuring a positive human impact, free from financial obligations. Concerns about AI potentially threatening humanity are highlighted, with Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking expressing warnings about its existential risks. Conversely, some experts argue that the threat remains remote. Open AI's mission is to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, ensuring it is distributed safely and evenly. Only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged will be utilized in the near future.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, has received overwhelming support after carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June. Despite his severe brain injury affecting his speech, his personality and humor remain intact. He has garnered thousands of Facebook friend requests, limited to 5,000 by the platform, and has inspired many through his resilience and ongoing rehabilitation efforts. His mother, Diane, noted the phenomenal response and increased mail and email traffic. Facebook suggested he consider a public page or use the subscribe feature for managing his large following. Ben continues to raise money for military charities and serves as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits.

In 2011, the poverty rate remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, following three years of increases. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance declined from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty in the US peaked at 15.1% in 2010.

The 25-year-old cricketer, Jos Buttler, moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new deal keeping him with the club until 2019. Known as a short-format specialist, Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and contribution to the team's success, highlighting his impact in the T20 Blast final and his positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler, currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, is set to return to Lancashire for the T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Interested bidders had until 23 January to register, with final bids being prepared for viewings in late February and March. No preservation proposals have been submitted. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports UK recyclers but prefers saving at least one frigate for a reef or diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options for the best financial return. The Type 22 frigates, originally anti-submarine ships, evolved into powerful surface combatants with comprehensive weapons systems and excellent command facilities, typically carrying a crew of about 280.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant instability due to racial and political tensions, marked by four coups. The 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians led to international isolation and economic harm, particularly to tourism. A 2000 coup by George Speight further damaged the economy and international reputation. In 2006, a bloodless military takeover occurred, leading to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. Fiji agreed to hold elections in 2014, resulting in its re-instatement to the Commonwealth. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with indigenous Fijians now forming a small majority. The economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, but faces trade and budget deficits, making Fiji a major recipient of aid.

Syria is making efforts to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad cited attacks on shipments by terrorist groups as a reason for the delay. He condemned US Secretary of State John Kerry's criticism of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where numerous civilian casualties have been reported. The Syrian government denies using barrel bombs on civilian areas and accuses the US of supporting terrorist elements. There are conflicting reports about the control of Aleppo's central prison, with the government claiming to have thwarted an attack, while opposition groups say rebels have seized it. Only about 4% of Syria's declared chemical weapons stockpile has been removed so far, raising concerns about the UN-backed plan's schedule. Russia, a key ally, expects the transfer of weapons to the coast for removal by ship to be completed by 1 March. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons acknowledges that security concerns have slowed the destruction process.

Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" is the favorite to win the 2014 Booker Prize, which is now open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, and Richard Flanagan), two Americans (Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler), and an Australian (Richard Flanagan). Jacobson, a previous winner, is nominated for "J," while Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" is the best-selling shortlisted book. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with coverage on BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

The passage details a legal battle involving a celebrity referred to as PJS, who is fighting to maintain his anonymity in the media regarding allegations of extra-marital activities. Initially, a High Court judge refused to impose an injunction barring publication of the story by The Sun on Sunday. However, PJS successfully appealed, resulting in a ban on identifying him in publications within England and Wales. News Group Newspapers sought to lift this ban, arguing that the story had already spread widely online and internationally. The Court of Appeal judges ruled against PJS, stating that confidentiality was likely lost due to the widespread nature of the allegations. PJS has now appealed to the Supreme Court, which will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction preventing the disclosure of PJS's identity will remain in place until the conclusion of the Supreme Court hearing.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was recently purchased for Â£345.5 million. The new owners are planning improvements to address parking, traffic congestion, and the overall appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, noted that the new owners view Fosse Park as a significant investment and aim to enhance its appearance as the gateway from Blaby into the city. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to improve parking and congestion issues, as well as the quality of common areas and facilities to ensure Fosse Park reaches its full potential.

The highly-anticipated film faced controversy in Malaysia due to its inclusion of a "gay moment," leading Disney to delay its release for a content review. Despite the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approving the film with a minor edit related to the gay moment, the release date remains uncertain. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, yet the tourism minister criticized the ban as "ridiculous." The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification," and LPF Chairman Datuk Abdul Hamid confirmed approval but noted that screening dates and locations are beyond their control. Local cinemas are offering refunds for pre-purchased tickets. Director Bill Condon highlighted the "exclusively gay moment" involving character LeFou, which has drawn both criticism and support from the public.

Landlords renting properties to more than three unrelated people must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost up to Â£1,000, despite the risk of fines up to Â£20,000 for non-compliance, according to Southampton City Council. The council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants often fear eviction and live in poorly maintained properties due to the shortage of affordable homes, with Shelter receiving about five to six calls daily regarding this issue. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, designated areas for HMO licensing include Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (introduced in 2013), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (introduced in 2015). While most landlords cooperate, a minority resist applying for licences, leading to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals by the council.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and MicheÃ¡l Martin of Fianna FÃ¡il aim to prevent a second election. Fianna FÃ¡il plans to facilitate a minority government but will not support a government program. Water charges are a significant obstacle in reaching an agreement. Proposals include a commission to consider the future of Irish Water. Fianna FÃ¡il demands the immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael supports their continued role. After the election, Fine Gael holds 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party has formed a majority government, and a taoiseach has yet to be elected.

The Sorrento, a ferry traveling to Valencia, experienced a fire on one of its car decks approximately 27km from Mallorca. The blaze quickly escalated, leading to the evacuation of all passengers and crew onto lifeboats. They were subsequently rescued by another ship, the Puglia. At least three individuals were injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt, and were transported to the hospital via helicopter. The cause of the fire remains unclear. Multiple ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue operation. The rescued passengers are en route back to Palma de Mallorca, expected to arrive shortly. Psychologists have been requested to provide counseling at the port. The Sorrento, owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, may sink due to the fire damage.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about individuals, including students, claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. The Commission suggested that better integration of individual electoral registers managed by councils could help identify duplicate entries. Labour cautioned against making it more difficult for young people to register to vote. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registrations after the snap poll was called, with 2.9 million applications received. However, concerns over duplicate applications persisted, with an estimated 30-70% of applications in some areas being duplicates. The Commission called for clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, similar to those used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. Despite efforts to inform people not to re-register if they had already voted, the issue remained unresolved. The Commission emphasized that voting twice in a general election is an offense punishable by an unlimited fine and called for a system to cross-check entries to reduce the risk of double voting. Labour's Cat Smith warned against measures that could exclude young people and students from registering to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player who had a troubled career and life, is believed to have killed himself while in prison. He was a star at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s and played for several NFL teams until 1999. Phillips faced numerous legal issues, including convictions for assault, and was serving a term of over 30 years. He was placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge recently found sufficient evidence to try him for Soward's death. Phillips' former coach described him as intelligent with good qualities but noted his struggles with anger and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester celebrating the regiment's eight-year anniversary. The promotion, awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams, was given for "good behaviour." Derby XXX is part of a lineage of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century, with the first Private Derby acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot. He joined the Mercian Regiment in 2014, has an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. Throughout his career, he has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, with Dejan Lovren scoring in injury time. The match was characterized by high emotion, drama, and exceptional football, played against the backdrop of Jurgen Klopp's intense coaching style and Thomas Tuchel's dignified approach. Liverpool, inspired by Klopp's leadership and the spirit of their 2005 Champions League win, overcame a 2-0 deficit with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Lovren. The victory moved Liverpool closer to a Champions League spot and into the Europa League semi-finals, where they will face Sevilla, Villarreal, or Shakhtar Donetsk. The match was marked by a remarkable atmosphere at Anfield, with fans and players alike embodying Klopp's mantra of never giving up.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK government representative Mr. Davis pledged to keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations and proposed monthly meetings for a "two-way information flow." Mr. Russell from Scotland emphasized the need for transparency regarding the UK government's plans, particularly concerning EU market access and the single market. He stressed that single market membership is crucial for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government aims to appeal the High Court's judgment on triggering Article 50, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this appeal in the Supreme Court.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr examines Daisy, a cloned sheep, for signs of heat, swelling, crepitus, or lameness, which could indicate disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, four of which (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) are clones of Dolly, the first cloned mammal. These four are considered identical twin sisters to Dolly. The sheep undergo rigorous tests to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy. Concerns exist that cloning might transfer "age-memory," causing clones to age prematurely. Dolly died at six-and-a-half years from a virus and osteoarthritis, raising questions about cloning's impact on aging. The current study focuses on three age-related co-morbidities: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, which could significantly influence the future of cloning, are pending publication.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten filly, Shutter Speed, won the Musidora Stakes at York, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Despite challenging, soft ground conditions, jockey Frankie Dettori praised her performance and believes she will excel on better ground. Gosden plans to send Shutter Speed to Chantilly's Oaks instead of Epsom's Oaks, where his other horses, Enable and Coronet, are top contenders. In another race, Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes, finishing ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden is cautious about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may opt out of the Derby trial if conditions are unfavorable.

The passage describes the fluctuating performance of the British pound against major currencies, influenced by the uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU referendum. Initially, the pound weakened against the dollar and euro but showed signs of recovery before falling again. The "volatility index" reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign claimed the pound's retreat was to March levels, while it was down 0.2% against the dollar, 0.6% against the euro, and 1% against the yen. Investors were concerned by data indicating a decline in the chances of a Remain vote and global economic worries. With the referendum 10 days away, polls showed the Leave campaign ahead, causing further market anxiety. Analysts predict increased volatility in sterling if the race remains tight. Hedge funds are betting on further declines in sterling's value. Asian stock markets, particularly Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong's main index, saw significant falls due to Brexit concerns. The FTSE 100 in London ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group experiencing the largest decline. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that the pound had been strengthening since March and that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. Manager Cowley praised his team's performance against a strong Barrow side despite a tough start and a long journey. Barrow's unbeaten run reached nine games with this win, while Braintree's losing streak extended to three games. Cowley remained optimistic, highlighting the team's remarkable achievements so far and emphasizing the challenges ahead for their part-time squad.

The passage discusses a significant shift in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will gain the authority to make planning decisions, previously held by the Planning Service under Stormont's environment department. This change, set to take effect from April 2015, is seen as both an opportunity and a potential risk. Proponents, like Michael Corr of PLACE, view it as a chance for councils to develop community and development plans, emphasizing the need for politicians skilled in urban regeneration and planning. Conversely, critics, including Friends of the Earth, warn of potential discrimination and favoritism, reminiscent of the 1960s, and stress the importance of transparency and a strict code of conduct. The passage also touches on concerns about political donations and their disclosure, highlighting the debate around the Â£7,500 limit for declaring donations in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, resulting in severe injuries to her shoulder and left back leg, which had to be amputated. Despite the severity of her injuries, Teenie is described as "incredibly lucky" to have survived. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. Teenie is now learning to walk again. The incident has prompted calls for the Scottish government to implement licensing for airguns, a proposal that was opposed by a majority in a previous consultation. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Liverpool has signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa, making him their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. This move follows the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Benteke, a Belgium international, scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since joining from Genk in 2012. He aims to win trophies and reach significant goals with Liverpool. The club struggled for goals last season after selling Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, finishing sixth in the Premier League. Manager Brendan Rodgers has signed Benteke to strengthen the attack, alongside other forwards like Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to injury but returned to score 15 goals, helping Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge both express optimism about Benteke's potential at Anfield.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found no clear evidence of academic improvement from using tablet devices in schools. It surveyed 671 state and independent schools, revealing that tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% having one tablet per pupil. Despite the increasing use of tablets, researchers could not definitively link them to improved academic results. However, head teachers reported positive impacts, and tablets were found to motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. The study also highlighted the rapid integration of technology in young people's lives, with many pupils using devices for social media and videos, even in bed. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The role of technology in schools is expected to grow, with tablets becoming a standard part of education.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images offer a social history of the city and highlight changes in children's lives, including both play and work. The oldest photo, from 1887, shows the Rollo family at a fancy dress ball. Curator Kay Jones selected these images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections, aiming to depict both positive and challenging childhood experiences. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has terminated his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join a National League rival, potentially facing his former club on 18 February. Previously playing for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, Anderson is described by Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson as a leader-type player despite his relatively limited game experience for his age. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, has joined the Gulls pending international clearance. Keating, with prior stints at Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, is characterized by Nicholson as young, raw, but highly motivated.
