He expressed enjoyment in meeting Balotelli and interacting with the players, noting their reactions to his shots. Van Velzen also surprised Balotelli by unveiling his infamous slogan from a past Manchester City match.

Women diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed. A study found that this procedure, known as oophorectomy, reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60% in BRCA1 carriers. The study, involving 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations, showed a 20-year survival rate of 77.4%. Oophorectomy was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death for BRCA1 carriers but not for BRCA2 carriers. The procedure also led to a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was immediate and lasted for 15 years. The study authors called for further research, particularly on BRCA2 carriers and those who undergo oophorectomy within a year of diagnosis.

On Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak Train No. 80, the Carolinian, which was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. The accident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property shortly before 10 AM. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, though a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The Lowes were pronounced dead at the scene. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey. A local man who met the couple suggested they may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, Toro is now facing deportation as he has not been granted citizenship and is technically living in the US illegally. His work with the DEA was crucial in taking down figures like cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, the DEA refused to help him obtain citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro fears for his life if deported back to Colombia, stating he would be dead within the first four hours. He remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

The US body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge exorbitant fees from celebrities and companies to remove negative domains. Domains like youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, and kevinspacey.sucks have been purchased. Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift are among those who have paid to have their names removed. ICANN has sent a letter to US and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. Initially approved by ICANN, the '.sucks' domain is now under scrutiny after complaints from industry groups. Vox Populi charges $2,499 a year for the domain, with most being resold for around $2,000. The company defends its practice as within ICANN rules and the law, but an advisory body has called it a 'shakedown scheme.'

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body, found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating in a village pond, was discovered. The case was reviewed, leading to the exhumation of the boy's body from his grave in Norfolk. DNA evidence identified the mother, who was arrested on suspicion of infanticide. However, the charge was dropped after she explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. The baby was reburied at Weasenham St Peter Church, Norfolk. Police ruled out foul play and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of Young's moving taxi. Young, mistakenly believing Hicks was planning to avoid payment, drove him back to the rank, leading Hicks to jump out at over 20mph. Hicks developed epilepsy and requires round-the-clock care. The High Court ruled Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, though the exact amount, expected to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, is yet to be decided. The judge reduced the damages by 50% due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving vehicle.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms led to reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly deadly. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas and Potosi, Missouri, where wind damage, flooding, and hail were also reported. The National Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago. Rockhold believes he needs a strong, dominant approach to defeat Machida, whom he plans to cut off and force into his own fighting style. He respects Machida's skills but is confident in his own abilities as a mixed martial artist. Machida, on the other hand, is confident in his technique and strategy, believing he can upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters are coming off victories and are well-prepared for the upcoming bout.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, approached the Aero Acres Residential Airpark for landing without deploying its landing gear. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, with its propellers hitting the tarmac and the wings bouncing from the impact. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, quickly re-engaged the engines and took off again, despite damage to the propellers. Remarkably, Georgaklis managed to fly the damaged aircraft 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The incident, likely caused by human error or a mechanical fault, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season but pledged to support the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the season. Despite City's intention to overhaul their ageing squad and listen to offers for Toure in the summer, Pellegrini dismissed the idea of giving Toure a rest, emphasizing his importance to the team. City's recent poor form has led to criticism of both Toure and Pellegrini, with goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledging the players' responsibility for the team's underperformance. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has cautioned Aaron Cresswell against moving to Manchester City, citing the limited playing time of previous English signings like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the 'Godfather of Uxbridge,' will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence, imposed by an Italian court in 1999 for Mafia association, was dropped. Rancadore, who lived in Britain under the alias Marc Skinner for over 20 years, lost his extradition battle in February but his case expired in October, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished if more than double the penalty period has passed. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, confirmed the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction due to its age. The case must still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore was arrested in 2013 and extradition proceedings were protracted, with concerns raised about Italian prison conditions and his serious heart condition. The Crown Prosecution Service admitted a mistake in failing to serve appeal papers on time, which may have contributed to the outcome.

Mr. Mole, AP McCoy's mount in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in a seven-runner lineup. Trained by Paul Nicholls, Mr. Mole is paired with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. Sprinter Sacre will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his final book of rides as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning. Notably, McCoy announced his retirement after winning at Newbury in February with Mr. Mole. Other participants in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was murdered in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body, an act she now regrets. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett, whose DNA matched evidence from the crime scene. Her body was found 33 days after her disappearance, hidden under a shower curtain and a child's wading pool near her home. Ritter's then-husband had advised her not to see the body or the photos, but she persisted and viewed them on a laptop with the help of the lead investigator, Mickey Miller. The sight of her daughter's conditionâincluding a black mouth, swollen face, vomit, pulled-out hair, and blood on her scalpâled Ritter to express a desire for revenge. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta National as the most important day of his career, which taught him valuable lessons. McIlroy aims to become the sixth player to win all four major titles, following Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. He has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances and is determined to win the green jacket, viewing it as a career-long goal. Despite personal distractions in the past year, including calling off his wedding and a legal dispute, McIlroy hopes to use the golf course as a sanctuary from pressure. He emphasizes the importance of focusing on his game and performing at his best to achieve his goal.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

This week saw several trending stories: after heavy rain in the New York area, four rainbows were spotted, captured by Amanda Curtis. In rural China, exotic dancers at wakes are becoming common but face a government crackdown. Robert Downey Jr. grew agitated during a private life interview. The #KylieJennerChallenge, involving lip plumping by sucking on a jar, trended. 102-year-old Alice Barker revisited her past with filmmakers. A prom proposal involving bombs was denied, leading to accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," and Johnny Deppâs transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer drew attention. A pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and a military dad photobombing his son also trended.

Last year, 272 children were hospitalized in England due to foetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by alcohol exposure in the womb, leading to brain damage and disabilities. Experts warn that the actual number affected could be much higher, with estimates suggesting at least one in 100 babies in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 cases annually. The condition is described as under-diagnosed and irreversible, with affected children facing lifelong challenges. The World Health Organization and advocacy groups call for stricter guidelines on alcohol consumption during pregnancy, recommending complete abstinence to prevent such outcomes.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as Boomerang Boy or Homing Pigeon Boy, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 PM. Wearing a mask and wielding an axe, he demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. However, owner Sab Dhillon tackled him, and his wife Sam hit McKerry with a baseball bat, disarming him. The police arrived and arrested McKerry, who pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in jail. McKerry, from Coundon near Bishop Auckland, has a history of crime, starting with shoplifting at age 12 and accumulating 80 arrests by age 15.

Four Royal Navy sailorsâJoshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalleyâhave been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in a Canadian barracks. They must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. They appeared in a Dartmouth courtroom, where they were granted bail under unusual conditions, including surrendering their passports and residing at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax. Bail was set at over Â£2,000 each. They are forbidden from contacting the victim or six witnesses, must stay within Nova Scotia, and cannot resign from the Navy without court permission. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after a hockey game. The sailors are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, offenses punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, with potential for additional charges based on forensic test results.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, faced a shocking incident when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse due to her four-year-old son RJ's appearance, which is caused by Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare disease affecting only about 70 people worldwide. RJ's skin appears red, inflamed, and scaly, leading to mistaken accusations of abuse. Valerie regularly applies creams to manage his condition, but they are often subjected to ignorant comments and taunts in public. Despite the challenges, Valerie remains devoted to her son, highlighting his cheerful nature and hoping for greater awareness of his condition as he grows.

Campaigners against Protein World's controversial "Are You Beach Body Ready?" adverts are celebrating as Transport for London (TfL) has decided to remove the posters from the London Underground. The ads, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked significant backlash from feminists and body image activists, leading to a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. Several posters were defaced, and the company received threats, including a bomb threat currently under police investigation. Despite the controversy, Protein World defended the campaign, stating it aimed to promote health and fitness. TfL confirmed the removal of the posters, noting the end of the three-week advertising period and promising to consider customer feedback for future ads.

Rail firms faced criticism for planning significant fare hikes, up to 87%, just ten days after the general election, despite major party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron urged First Great Western (FGW) to review its decision to nearly double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency. Cameron and Labour had promised to freeze fares and cap price hikes, respectively. FGW's planned 87% increase on an off-peak return from Charlbury to London, from Â£33.30 to Â£62.40, angered constituents and prompted Cameron's intervention. Train companies can increase unregulated fares, which make up about half of their revenue, three times a year. FGW claimed the hike aligned the North Cotswolds route with other services and offered cheaper advanced single tickets. Other notable hikes included a 24.5% increase on an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin, and a 22% increase on a first-class day return from Manchester to Stoke with Virgin. Virgin defended its hikes, stating most affected cheaper Virgin-only fares and that its overall increase was below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after confronting vandals who were throwing stones at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. When a brick broke his front window, he opened the door to remonstrate with the attackers and was struck in the left eye by another brick. Despite emergency surgery, his eyesight could not be saved. The attack occurred three weeks after his wedding to Elaine, 54. Police are investigating but have found no clear motive, suggesting it may have been random vandalism. The couple, feeling unsafe, plans to move away from the neighborhood.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension following his successful return from a leg injury sustained in a 2014 road accident that also resulted in the death of his father. Poynton, a former England under-19 international, underwent ankle surgery and made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the season and is now committed to the county until the end of 2016. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's character and work ethic, expressing hope that the new contract will boost his confidence and performance.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To help him through his treatment, which included 80 days of chemotherapy, a kidney tumor removal operation, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, he created a superhero mask inspired by Ninja Turtles. His bravery and the mask's significance gained attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon and a Little Star Award from Cancer Research UK. After a year-long battle, Harley was declared cancer-free and will undergo regular check-ups. His family is overjoyed and looking forward to his return to school full-time.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Sherwood, impressed by Grealish's performance in the FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, emphasizes the importance of Grealish continuing to secure his place in the Villa first team. Grealish, who is 19, is currently sought after by both the Republic of Ireland and England for international representation. Sherwood suggests that Grealish should play more for Aston Villa before making a decision on his international allegiance. Grealish's father, Kevin, also supports the idea that Jack should prioritize his club football. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season, with both countries hoping to secure his commitment.

The passage discusses the high landing fees for private jets at various airports around the world, highlighting the luxury and expense associated with private jet travel. It notes that while private jet travel is a growing trend, with millions of flights recorded annually in the US and Europe, the industry is primarily accessible to the wealthy due to the high costs, including landing fees that can reach thousands of dollars per landing. The passage lists the top 10 most expensive airports for landing fees, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive at Â£4,559 ($6,850) per landing. Other notable airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, and Dublin Airport in Ireland. The passage also mentions popular routes and the cost of flights during major events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her Labrador, Cooper, and his friend Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy takes ladylike licks, Cooper quickly devours his cone in one bite. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, ensures Daisy eats first due to Cooper's fast eating habit. The video of this outing has garnered over seven million views. Despite some criticism for feeding her dogs ice cream, Gallegos defends her actions, noting Cooper's good health and her late dog Sammy's similar treat routine. Another video shows the dogs visiting Starbucks for a 'pup-uccino,' with Cooper again quickly consuming the whipped cream.

Gary Locke, former Hearts boss, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after a successful interim period. He joined Kilmarnock as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer but took over when Johnston quit in February. Locke, 41, has lost only once in seven games since assuming control. He signed a three-year deal and will address the media at a press conference on Friday.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. Kemp applies the Doterra oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Teachers at the school warned that Logan would be removed from class because the oils' smell was a distraction to other students. Kemp received a letter from the local school board stating the oils had created a 'problem' for staff and students. Despite the threat of suspension, Kemp plans to fight the decision, asserting the oils' positive impact on her son. Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, citing it as a 'health issue'. Doterra has not yet commented on the situation.

On Wednesday at 3 PM, a fire broke out at a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, destroying 90 condos and causing the building to collapse. The blaze, whose origin is unknown, was so intense that it melted paint on nearby buildings. Smoke from the fire was visible from three miles away, and 12 fire crews were deployed to combat the flames but were unable to enter the building. Residents, including Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, reported losing everything. The fire is under investigation, with initial claims suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper complex, used as a holiday home by residents between May and November, was significantly damaged.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, aged 88, enjoying a ride in Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma. Despite her age and a knee injury that has reduced her riding time, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrian, eschewing a helmet for a silk scarf due to her hair. She has a lifelong love for horses, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four, and continues to breed various horse and pony breeds, including Fell ponies and Highland ponies. The Queen's Fell ponies, like Carltonlima Emma, are part of an ancient breed that has been prized since the Neolithic period and were used by various historical groups including the Romans and Vikings. Today, Fell ponies are popular for their gentle nature and are bred by the Queen at her Hampton Court stud.

A dispute over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors, Leon Yeaman (55) and Phillip Pama (28), resulted in tragedy when Yeaman was allegedly killed by a single punch from Pama. The incident occurred on Thursday night when Yeaman was making noise in his yard. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift, was sleeping at the time and confronted Yeaman after being awakened. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling. During the confrontation, Pama allegedly struck Yeaman blindly, leading to his death. Paramedics were unable to revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama, who has no history of violence, was granted conditional bail and must surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the police twice a week. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (Â£1,400) for the hit, specifying that she wanted him to suffer by having his arms, legs, and kidneys damaged before she would "finish him." Police conducted a sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman, and arrested Simonova after she handed over part of the payment. She now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder.

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho discusses his daily prayers and strong faith in God, emphasizing that he never prays about football. He maintains a clear separation between his professional and family life, asserting that he is a good family person and friend. Mourinho, who has worked as an ambassador against hunger with the World Food Programme, acknowledges his competitive and emotional nature in his professional role but stresses that his personal life is distinct. Chelsea is currently leading the league and set to play against QPR. Mourinho was previously fined Â£25,000 for alleging a campaign against Chelsea. He only regularly attends church in Portugal.

On April 1, Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price Is Right" for 35 years before retiring in 2007, made a surprise return at 91 years old. He took charge of the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over hosting duties to Drew Carey. Barker's return marked the first time in eight years that he appeared on the show, and he seamlessly resumed his role despite the long absence.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who was part of the foreign missions branch, had his security clearance revoked and was placed on leave. His arrest follows another incident where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for misconduct, and an earlier incident involving two high-ranking officials driving into a secure White House area after drinking. These incidents are under investigation by the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at the city's safari park by approaching a hungry lion to within 10 feet to capture images with just a camera. The clicking sound of the camera alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to rapidly retreat. He described the lion treating him like prey and nearly being attacked, scrambling back into his car. Saeed reflected that while he was laughing during the incident, he doubts he would attempt such a dangerous shot again.

The NYPD has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman, aged between 25 and 45, who was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn's Gravesend section. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, believed to be a faded heart with the name 'Monique' etched on a ribbon topped with a rose. The police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and are seeking information from the public to identify the woman. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returned from the UK in 2009 and, unable to afford property, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck over a year and a half. The wood and steel house, costing about $25,000, is located in Nelson, New Zealand, and features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is nearly self-sufficient with solar power and water from a nearby spring. They plan to build another similar home in the future.

Researchers, led by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University, found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not use iPads or use them individually. The study involved 352 kindergarten students in a Midwestern suburban school district over an academic year. Shared iPad users scored about 30 points higher than individual iPad users and non-iPad users. Blackwell suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, is key to the improved outcomes. She recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness. Blackwell's findings will be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its two front trotters. The heartwarming video, featured on People's Daily Online, shows the piglet wobbling and foraging for food, often close to tipping over but always regaining balance. Named 'Super Pig,' it lives with its siblings, all born with four legs, on a farm in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China. Farmer Ms. Duan noticed the piglet's condition during feeding and has since attracted villagers' attention. This isn't the first two-legged animal to gain fame in China; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became popular for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car on lap 25. Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel, spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center, received stitches for a leg cut, and was subsequently released. The race saw many cars struggling with traction due to prior rain, and Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. The horrific act, captured on CCTV, occurred in their Rio de Janeiro apartment. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. He yelled at her, calling her a 'slut' before the attack. Sena was a member of the dance group Jaula das Gostozuedas. A neighbor heard the argument and gunshots. After the murder, Severiano stole a car but was arrested after a crash. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life in jail.

In a candid interview, Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal battle with mental illness, which led her to contemplate suicide. Wilson explained that her anxiety made her feel that life had no existential purpose and she couldn't see a way out. Factors contributing to her crisis included mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation due to not having a husband or children. She emphasized the intrinsic link between depression and anxiety and called for greater acknowledgment of this connection to better address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson now accepts herself as an anxious person and believes anxiety is becoming the "new depression." The Beyond Blue report indicates that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. For support, contact Beyond Blue at 1300 224 636 or Lifeline at 13 11 14.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she attacked her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and, after asking her to leave and being refused, struck her with the crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was 'completely justified in her outrage' under Oregon law, which allows for the use of physical force against an intruder. Curtin's defense attorney highlighted the ex-girlfriend's history of harassment and threats. Curtin, who gave birth in January, would have faced a mandatory six-year prison sentence if convicted. The boyfriend, the father of Curtin's child, has a history of heroin use and is not involved in the new child's life. Curtin has since moved on and is living with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed being fed treats at home. Her owner attempted to trick her by adding a broccoli spear to the mix. Upon tasting the broccoli, Gemma displayed a look of disgust, chewed briefly, and then spat it out on the floor. The passage humorously suggests that the two children living with Gemma should not emulate her aversion to vegetables. Besides eating, Gemma is shown in other videos enjoying sleep and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page. This occurred when users attempted to access the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which had been discontinued in 2011. The pornographic site took over the URL after the awards were scrapped and the registration was allowed to expire. HSBC removed the hyperlink and denied any association with the external site, issuing a public apology for the inconvenience. The bank assured that its website and internet banking services remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus from Maryland called 911 when a fire broke out on the first floor of his home. He and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call, Marcus provided firefighters with instructions on how to reach them, stayed calm, and reassured his sister. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window, rescued Marcus and Aaliyah, and provided them with a gas mask. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar Hospital.

The passage describes the emergence of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the neon glow illuminating a popular beach, describing the sight as a 'beautiful supernatural scene' caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn, primarily due to natural causes. The algae emits a luminous glow as a defense mechanism.

New tests that identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors can determine the aggressiveness of the cancer and the likelihood of recurrence, potentially sparing patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, and results indicating a low risk (as low as 5%) can be provided within days. This risk assessment is comparable to or better than the outcomes of chemotherapy, which has severe side effects. Most breast cancer patients currently undergo chemotherapy post-surgery to prevent recurrence, but these new tests, such as EndoPredict, may show that chemotherapy is unnecessary for some. These tests are currently available privately at a cost of about Â£2,500, but there is hope they will be adopted by the NHS. Experts argue that the cost of these tests could be offset by savings from avoiding chemotherapy. Patients like Becca Cornford, who faced a second breast cancer diagnosis, found relief in knowing that chemotherapy was not necessary based on her low-risk test results.

Over 25 pregnant women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships in the past nine years, including five from HMS Ocean and one from HMS Illustrious. A strict 'no touching' rule is in place at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. This follows the case of Commander Sarah West, the first female captain of a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back to the UK amid allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering they were pregnant, and 102 were evacuated from Iraq, due to strict military rules banning expectant mothers from serving in war zones.

A drone containing traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential drone-related terrorism. The discovery occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a move unpopular among many Japanese due to safety concerns following the Fukushima disaster. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle with the radioactive material, was found by a staff member. Although the amount of cesium is not immediately harmful, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed concerns about future terrorism attempts using drones, particularly at upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law currently restricts drone flights around airports but does not impose similar restrictions in most of Tokyo, including government buildings.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother to work with him daily on his motorbike. He ties a sash around both their waists to prevent her from falling off. This practice began after his father's death, as his wife works in a different city and his son is in school. He wakes her at 5 am, rides slowly to work (a four-kilometer journey taking an hour), and ensures she stays in her designated room at the bank where he works. Lu believes it's his duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to raising her children.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, primarily driven by rising rates among women. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men over the past month, and binge drinking as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month. The increase in binge drinking among women was more than seven times that of men. Factors contributing to this rise include changing social norms, increased affluence, cheaper alcohol due to unadjusted taxes, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. The study also noted that despite the increase in heavy drinking, the overall percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively stable.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to risks of infections, complications, disability, or death. In England, over a quarter of women giving birth have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This includes women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the caesarean rate should ideally be between 10% and 15%. The WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow the procedure even without medical justification. A planned caesarean costs the NHS Â£2,369 on average, compared to Â£1,665 for a natural birth.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' items in a yard sale. She has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her in his $800,000 summer home on Court Street in Edgartown. Filkins claimed ownership of the house before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup truck. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket upon arrival. Filkins was later arrested when she tried to re-enter the home. Items stolen include four deck chairs, a Weber grill, two side tables, an Ann Chase lamp, two Crate & Barrel lamps, two framed posters, various pots, pans, linens, and a painting by the owner. The Edgartown Police Department is asking anyone who received items from the home to return them and is offering assistance to victims seeking restitution.

Bella Crooke from Melbourne lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party. A security guard found it and left it at Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police officers, finding the phone unlocked, used it to post humorous selfies and messages on Bella's Facebook page to locate her. The posts, which included puns and reassurances about the phone's condition, garnered a humorous response from her friends. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone without needing to provide her name, as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police also engaged in humorous text exchanges with Bella's friends. Bella has since secured her phone with a password and expressed gratitude for the police's humor and efforts in returning her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed after being caught in a fight between two adult hippos at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged in the water by one of the fighting adults, while its mother watched in horror. The baby hippo died from its injuries hours later. The mother had stayed with her herd, possibly believing it was safer, but this decision proved fatal for the calf. Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, witnessed the incident and noted the mother's efforts to protect her baby from younger hippos earlier.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is on the market for Â£575,000. However, the property has only three years left on its lease, making the cost per year Â£191,000 or Â£15,000 per month, comparable to renting a similar flat in the area. The flat, located in Egerton Place, is described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft of space, including three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. It requires modernization. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth up to Â£6 million. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge is Â£1.5 million with a 28-year lease. The current freeholder is the Wellcome Trust, and extending the lease for 90 years could cost between Â£3.35 and Â£4.5 million. The property has attracted significant interest despite the short lease and need for renovation.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The outage, which began on Friday evening, was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. Despite the disruption, Starbucks assured customers that stores would open as usual on Saturday. The glitch prevented staff from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales, though some locations continued to accept cash. The incident led to widespread excitement on social media, with customers sharing photos of their free drinks. However, many stores closed early to avoid giving away products for free. Starbucks apologized for the inconvenience and assured customers that the issue had been resolved.

Terrorists are training and radicalizing Muslims in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Detective Constable Gareth Jones highlighted that these activities often involve seemingly ordinary community participation with ulterior motives. The issue of terrorism in Wales is not limited to large cities, with incidents dating back to 1998. Notable cases include the 2005 7/7 bombers training in North Wales and the 2010 arrest of an Al-Qaeda-inspired gang plotting attacks. Michael Adebowale, convicted in the murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby, also had connections to a Welsh institute. DC Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence in combating these threats.

A previously feared-extinct Omura's whale was discovered washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, DNA profiling confirmed it as an Omura's whale. Environment Minister Albert Jacob highlighted the significance of this find for whale scientists, as the species was only described in scientific journals in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale, a 5.68 m juvenile female, has unique skeletal features including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses the role of hormones in leadership, particularly in the context of presidential candidates. It highlights a Texas businesswoman's controversial view that Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president due to potential irrationality from her hormones, contrasting this with historical instances where male leaders' decisions were impaired by testosterone. The passage argues that women leaders generally take fewer unnecessary risks and cites studies supporting this. It also points out the bias against women in the workplace and politics, emphasizing that gender bias, not biochemistry, is the real obstacle for female candidates like Clinton. The passage concludes by advocating for the eradication of gender stereotypes and bias, highlighting the benefits of equality and diversity in leadership.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning his extensive collection of over 200 antiques to downsize his home. The collection, valued at Â£100,000, includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture, a longbow, a self-portrait with a longbow, paintings, swords, rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century. The auction, featuring 238 lots, will be held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire. Hardy, a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, expressed sadness at selling his collection but hopes future owners will enjoy it as much as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man suspected of murdering his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. He has been on the run since failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day. The investigation suggests foul play, and authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed the cause of death. Shemansky, who is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness, was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself if he arrives at her home. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, which bypassed the usual bidding process due to a perceived unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council's decision to grant Eugene the 2021 event was influenced by a recent presentation that demonstrated the city's capability to stage the championships. IAAF President Lamine Diack highlighted the strategic decision as an opportunity to access a key market and benefit the global development of the sport. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in a plot to steal his winnings. Granger, 25, targeted Hassan, 56, at a London casino, using her appearance to befriend him. She left his flat door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, to enter, tie him up, and fatally assault him while searching for his hidden money. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. All defendants were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas has struggled during the second half of the season, notably in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland, where he was rated poorly. Despite a strong start, his form has dipped, raising questions about his durability. Fabregas' performance has declined, with only one assist in his last five games, impacting his chances of breaking Thierry Henry's Premier League assists record. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas' fatigue and is hoping for a resurgence to aid the team's title push.

West Ham is in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshan Beckford, who has impressed during a trial with their academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets for the 2016-17 season at the Olympic Stadium will start at Â£289, making it the cheapest pricing strategy in the Premier League to encourage attendance at the 54,000-capacity stadium.

Police have halted their investigation into a violent assault on huntsman Mike Lane, despite substantial evidence implicating suspected attackers. Lane, 40, was attacked by masked protesters wielding iron bars and ropes, resulting in concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of saboteurs, were provided to Wiltshire Police. Despite this, the police have shelved the inquiry due to insufficient evidence, a decision Lane and others find disheartening. The attack occurred during a hunt using an artificial scent, not a live fox, and involved protesters spraying hounds with citronella to distract them. Wiltshire Police confirmed the investigation is on hold pending further information, but the failure to identify, charge, or prosecute anyone has dismayed hunt supporters.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen known as the "American mouthpiece of al Qaeda," was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, who converted to Islam and joined al Qaeda, was a prominent propagandist for the organization, appearing in videos threatening attacks and urging Muslims to target American interests. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. Gadahn was not specifically targeted in the operation that killed him, which also resulted in the death of another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, and U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies, exemplified by a viral video of a five-year-old boy, Mai Zizhuo, showcasing exceptional basketball skills. Mai, who has been playing since he was two and a half, performs impressive feats such as scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His skills have garnered widespread attention and admiration in China, sparking comparisons to the country's renowned basketball star, Yao Ming. The video has elicited thousands of comments from stunned netizens, some questioning the authenticity of the footage and others expressing envy or admiration for Mai's talent.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals,' attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25, chaired by comedian John Cleese, to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, formed in response to the phone-hacking scandal, aims to establish a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement is likely to cause embarrassment to Hacked Off, given PIE's controversial history, including its alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied for lowering the age of sexual consent to ten and legalizing incest.

On Thursday, Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. This unusual setting attracted crowds who watched from the club's balcony. Models showcased a monochrome, unisex collection designed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, which can be worn in 20 different ways. Guests enjoyed refreshments and the beautiful ocean backdrop during the show, which took place on a warm, sunny day. Passers-by also stopped to watch the event.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California, where he interacted with various animals including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, Khan enjoyed the outing at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight would be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, dismissing speculation about potential bouts with British rival Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name temporarily placed on an Israeli memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His family and the organization Almagor, which supports terror victims in Israel, objected to his inclusion. Abu Khdeir's father, Hussein, stated he was not consulted and refused his son's name to be listed among "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor CEO Meir Indor described the teen's death as a rogue attack and not an act of terror, demanding his name be removed. Following these complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial. His name has already been taken off the memorial's website. A panel of judges began hearing evidence against the three suspects in January.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, captured footage of his young son using the family cat's belly as a pillow in the garden. The video shows the cat initially licking its fur before the boy jumps on it. The cat, after a brief stillness, gets up and moves to another spot, with the boy following. This sequence repeats twice more before the cat leaves. A later video shows the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales. Kushner, one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government, claimed that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, his past charges, including a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI, came to light. Kushner maintains he never intended to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, with defense lawyers arguing the case is based on unreliable witnesses.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, which produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast, caused by an oil leak at an oil storage facility, led to a large fire. Five of the injured were hurt by broken glass and hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters were deployed, and the fire is now under control. Local residents reported hearing the explosion and feeling tremors. The plant had a previous explosion in 2013 without casualties. The construction of PX plants has led to protests in China due to pollution concerns, resulting in the Zhangzhou plant being relocated from Xiamen to a more remote area in 2007.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, maintains a superstition of wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads, despite referees' requests to change. He believes this practice has protected him from shin injuries. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction despite the outcome and gratitude for the manager's faith in him.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been diagnosed with global and irreversible brain damage by her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive. Cissy Houston expressed sadness over the possibility of Bobbi Kristina living in this condition for a lifetime and hopes for a miracle. A source confirmed that Bobbi Kristina has shown no neurological improvement for nearly three months, not responding to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow movement. She has a tracheostomy. This contrasts with recent statements by Bobby Brown, who claimed his daughter was awake and watching him. An attorney for the family stated that while Bobbi Kristina's condition has improved, the quality of her future life remains uncertain as she begins a long rehabilitation process.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova faced challenges from Lisicki's powerful play, while both players struggled with their serves. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, already affected by last week's severe weather, are warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, similar to the system that caused three days of heavy rain and wind last week, could impact the region again, with heavy rain expected from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned about the potential for further storms to hinder ongoing clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 of 24,196 requests for assistance still pending. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills highlighted the Hunter region as particularly at risk due to previous flooding and high winds. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott noted that while a trough of low pressure is forming along the coast, the heaviest impact is expected in the far northern parts of the state. The Bureau of Meteorology's Barry Hanstrum added that the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds are likely to be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coast, with heavy falls also expected in southeast Queensland. The SES is urging the community to prepare their homes and families to mitigate further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide. Instead, she explained on Instagram that she was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Moric posted photos of bruises on her arms and clarified that she fell and hurt herself at home. She expressed shock at the suicide claims and assured her followers that she is fine and only needs rest. Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially suggested she had tried to commit suicide, but Moric refuted this, stating he was in Naples at the time of her accident. Moric, who was once married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, reassured her fans that she is recovering at home.

As Kate and William await the arrival of their second child, the British public hopes for a traditional name. A recent poll shows that if the baby is a girl, the favorite name is Diana (12% of votes), in honor of William's mother, Diana, Princess of Wales. Other popular names for a girl are Alice and Charlotte (both 9%), with Alice being the name of the Queen's aunt and Charlotte a nod to William's father, Charles. For a boy, the preferred names are James (13%) and Alexander. Despite this, 25% of the 2,200 polled hope for a girl, compared to only 3% hoping for a boy. The poll also indicates strong support (68%) for William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

In eastern Afghanistan, a suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the protesters, including MP Humayoon Humayoon, were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied the group's involvement, and no other organization has claimed responsibility. The report was contributed to by CNN's Masoud Popalzai, Jethro Mullen, and Elizabeth Joseph.

Dani Alves is expected to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The Brazilian right-back, who has spent seven successful years at Barcelona winning four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues, could not agree to a new deal. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves turned down a three-year contract extension contingent on him participating in 60% of matches. Santana stated that negotiations are over and expressed frustration that contract renewal discussions only began in April.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a perfect fit due to their South American-style play and would be highly appreciated by the fans at La Bombonera. He specifically mentioned Pirlo, a top-tier midfielder, and Totti, a Roma legend, as the two players he would like to see make the move to Boca Juniors.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton, which has garnered significant attention online. Despite the dramatic incident, which involved a double somersault and left him with only a cut on his nose, Ferguson returned to work the next day, mucking out stables as usual. He remains undeterred and plans to continue riding. The fall has made him an internet sensation and earned him some banter and new followers on Twitter.

The passage discusses the release of the movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron" and the excitement surrounding it, particularly focusing on James Haskell, the London Wasps captain. Haskell, an England flanker, posted a photo on Instagram dressed as Iron Man, a character played by Robert Downey Jr. in the movie. The movie premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre, attracting fans eager to see the star-studded cast, which includes Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who has played rugby in various countries including France, Japan, and New Zealand, returned to the London Wasps in 2012 after spells with other clubs. Since his return, he has made over 100 appearances for the Wasps and has 57 caps for the England squad.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a significant trend for Spring/Summer 2015 (SS15). This style, available in various forms such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped, offers an alternative to the long-dominant skinny jeans. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp endorse wide-leg trousers for their effortless appeal and ability to provide a different look. The trend, which harkens back to the 1970s, can be intimidating due to the large amount of fabric, but styling tips include pairing with high-heeled shoes to elongate the leg and keeping the top simple to maintain proportion. Denim is highlighted as the easiest way to adopt the trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering versions. The wide-leg silhouette is seen on various catwalks, including Gucci and Celine, and can be found in both high-end and high-street fashion. The trend is versatile for different occasions, from casual to evening wear, and can be explored further at astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it. The movie, part of the UMIX social event series, stars Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, who was fatally shot in 2013. Some students opposed the film due to its depiction of the Iraq War, which they felt negatively portrayed the Middle East and its people. The university, located in an area with a large Arab-American population, faced a backlash and a counter-petition urging reconsideration. E. Royster Harper, the university's vice president for student life, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression. As an alternative, UMIX will screen "Paddington" for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper." The decision was praised by Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

On April 3, two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly attempted to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia. The quokka, though singed, survived the incident. Detectives investigated, seized video evidence, and charged the men with animal cruelty. They were evicted from the island and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, similar in size to domestic cats, are native to small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, was reunited with footage of her performances through the efforts of filmmakers and volunteers. Barker, who had never seen any of the motion pictures made of her and had lost her photographs and memorabilia over the years, was shown a video compilation of "soundies" (early music videos) at her nursing home. She expressed delight, describing the experience as "just fabulous."

The passage highlights a decline in the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain. A study by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31% of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car. Factors contributing to this decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicles, and increased weekend activities like shopping and watching live football. Only 12% of those who do wash their cars do so regularly. Additionally, only 5% of respondents have asked their children to wash the car for extra money. Brits are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield having the highest weekly washing rates, and Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh the lowest. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most frequently washed by owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least often. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley notes the shift from a national tradition to a less common practice due to time constraints and available professional services.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's significant impact on him since Gerrard's arrival at Anfield in 2008, but believes Liverpool can manage the challenge of replacing him. Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead his team to the final against Arsenal. If Liverpool wins, Gerrard will conclude his Anfield career in the final on May 30, his birthday, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool. Despite acknowledging the difference Gerrard's departure will make, Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements and the team can adapt with the right support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are expected to return to the lineup after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit an ace at Augusta National during the par-3 contest, achieving a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole. This marked his first ace at Augusta. Nicklaus played alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, who celebrated his achievement. Despite Nicklaus' accomplishment, the day saw five hole-in-ones, matching the 2002 record, with Camilo Villegas also achieving two aces but losing the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters winner and the youngest to wear a green jacket in 1963, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms led to reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, moving northeast and missing the city but posing risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of potentially deadly nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas and Potosi, Missouri, where wind damage, flooding, and hail were also reported. More storms are expected in the Midwest and surrounding areas on Thursday.

Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates was granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas, drawing criticism from Harris' family for perceived apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. He claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized. There are allegations that Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff, which the sheriff's office denies. Bates' training records were released to show he had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla tattoo. McGregor claims greater motivation than Aldo for the title, stating Aldo lacks the same desire. The fighters have a contentious relationship, highlighted by McGregor grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners for skolling a beer at an Australian Rules function, which they argued glorified binge drinking and associated masculinity with alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, criticized Abbott for showcasing his masculinity in this manner, stating it promotes a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing. Abbott's actions were cheered by the crowd but drew ire from critics who believe he should advocate against binge drinking. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, arguing his overall fitness regimen sets a positive example. The incident highlighted changing attitudes towards heavy drinking and the expectation for public figures to set responsible examples.

In Indiana, there has been a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 last week. This outbreak, primarily among intravenous drug users and involving the painkiller Opana, has led to an epidemic declaration. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has distributed 5,322 clean syringes and collected 1,400 used ones. Despite the program's initial success, the rising number of cases may pressure Pence to extend it beyond April 25. The future of the program and similar initiatives in other counties remains uncertain, with concerns about funding and the potential promotion of drug use. The outbreak highlights the link between high rates of hepatitis C and potential HIV outbreaks due to needle-sharing.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a detailed quiz about the football club. The test, styled like a school exam, included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and creative sections. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), impressing her boyfriend who decided not to dump her. She posted the test on Twitter, garnering mixed reactions. Saskia struggled with some questions, such as naming the full starting squad and player positions, but her creative answers, like comparing Alexis Sanchez to Eden Hazard, earned her extra points. Her boyfriend marked her answers with a red pen, providing feedback and even drawing an angry face for incorrect answers. Despite some criticism, many praised Saskia's knowledge and her boyfriend's dedication.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years in exchange for promised US citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, Toro faces deportation as his citizenship was never granted, leaving him in the US illegally. His work significantly contributed to the prosecution of high-profile figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his valuable service, the DEA refused to assist with his citizenship, leading Toro to fear for his life if deported back to Colombia. He remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport.

A 14-year-old girl in India allegedly set herself on fire after being gang-raped by five men from her village in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. She is currently fighting for her life in Delhiâs Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. The accused men have been arrested. This incident comes amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following recent attacks and protests calling for more protection for women. The issue gained further attention after officials banned a documentary about the gang rape and murder of a student in Delhi, fearing it would cause further disorder.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is eager to beat rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie, who is not deemed fit enough to play despite claiming he is ready. Van Gaal also ruled out Luke Shaw for the same reason. The manager sees an opportunity to secure a higher league position, potentially finishing second or third, which would avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal emphasized the importance of controlling aggression and learning from past defeats. Key players like Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, Angel di Maria, and Radamel Falcao were seen in training. Van Gaal expressed his appreciation for the fans' support and is looking forward to the derby atmosphere.

During a Barclays Premier League match between Arsenal and Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium, a section of fans from both clubs protested against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of the game. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. Fans expressed disgust over the increasing ticket prices, especially in light of the Premier League's recent Â£5.14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets for the sold-out match started at Â£64, which protesters deemed extortionate. Banners displayed inside and outside the stadium highlighted the disparity between the league's revenue and ticket prices, with one reading, "Â£5bn and what do we get? Â£64 a ticket." The protesters aim to raise awareness about the financial struggles fans face and hope to see tangible reductions in ticket prices aligned with working-class incomes. Further protests are anticipated after the match.

A newborn baby named Star, diagnosed with the life-threatening liver condition biliary atresia shortly after birth, underwent a successful liver transplant from her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, who is the twin sister of Star's mother, Jade Reader. Neither of Star's parents were suitable matches for the transplant. Shanell volunteered without hesitation to donate part of her liver, saving Star's life. Star has since made a good recovery and will require regular blood and liver function tests, as well as anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life.

In Audi's football challenge, Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in various head-to-head competitions involving Audi cars. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by firing balls into the boot of a car. The second round, played over a makeshift tennis court with an Audi R8 V10 Plus as the net, was also won by Hazard and Ake, giving them a 6-0 lead. The final round involved shooting balls from long range into convertible Audis, which Remy and Willian won despite Willian accidentally smashing a wing mirror during the challenge.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy (24) and Jason Timmons (29), along with their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal, contrary to prosecutors' claims that he intended to kill himself when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph into the couple's SUV. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus' death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. His defense attributed the crash to a combination of Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis symptoms. Dellinger's wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity, while he expressed devastation over the victims' deaths.

Lacey Spears, from Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt, resulting in his death. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, avoiding the maximum sentence of 25 years to life. Spears showed no emotion during the sentencing. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison. The judge noted Spears suffers from a mental illness, and the crime was described as 'unfathomable in its cruelty.'
