Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's main opposition party al-Wefaq, emphasized the necessity for the government to demonstrate a willingness to offer concrete solutions for meaningful national dialogue. He called for a representative from the royal family to engage in dialogue, highlighting Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist figure. Hardliners within the government, led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, oppose dialogue, fearing it will embolden opposition demands. Despite this, Sheikh Salman welcomed dialogue and believed it was essential, even though many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties. He advocated for working with reformists within the royal family, including the Crown Prince, who had previously agreed to a seven-point plan towards a constitutional monarchy before it was disrupted by GCC troops. Sheikh Salman expressed hope for more assertive US policy under Secretary of State John Kerry and criticized the UK government for its lack of public pressure on Bahrain to end violence and human rights abuses. He reiterated al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations and called for the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and human rights activists.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for later. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it globally for about 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. Colleagues and friends remember him for his generosity, academic prowess, and commitment to historically informed music.

In the year ending March, 57 homicides were recorded in Scotland, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. This represents a significant drop from nine years ago. Only one homicide case from 2015-16 remained unresolved by March 31, 2016. Sharp instruments, predominantly knives, were the most common method, accounting for 51% of homicides. Approximately 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts to reduce violent crime and support at-risk communities. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against over-optimism, noting past revisions of homicide figures and the rise in sexual and violent crimes.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking the first Premier League defeat for the Black Cats this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but they were unable to equalize despite creating numerous chances. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over the lack of goals, noting their previous high-scoring game against Hull. Sunderland's goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Bournemouth struggled to find an equalizer even after Sunderland's Steven Pienaar was sent off. Howe emphasized the importance of moving on from the loss despite the missed opportunities.

Mr. Abbott emphasized that stopping boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea, as Australia detains migrants attempting to reach its shores by boat and sends them to offshore processing camps for eventual resettlement elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and of "dubious legality," contrasting it with Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Despite this, Mr. Abbott reiterated his stance, citing the effectiveness of Australia's approach in stopping illegal boats. Additionally, Mr. Abbott sparked controversy by comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis, a comment deemed "injudicious and unfortunate" by Australian Jewish groups, who highlighted the fundamental differences between terrorism and state-implemented genocide.

The US has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia aimed at sustaining the cessation of hostilities in Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks on civilians, particularly in Aleppo. The US warned it would halt talks unless Moscow stopped bombing Aleppo, accusing Russia of failing to uphold its commitments and ensure Syrian regime adherence to agreed arrangements. Russia denies involvement in the deadly aid convoy strike and accuses the US of shifting blame. The suspension affects planned coordination meetings in Geneva and the withdrawal of US personnel, though counter-terrorism operations discussions will continue to prevent clashes.

Downing Street supports a Policy Exchange report suggesting that selling high-value vacant homes could raise Â£4.5bn annually, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. Labour opposes this, arguing it would displace low-income families. Policy Exchange claims this could create the largest social housing program since the 1970s and reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000. The prime minister's spokesman encourages councils to use their social housing stock efficiently. Labour proposes using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes. Policy Exchange defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the regional average, accounting for 21.8% of UK social housing stock. Critics argue this would segregate communities and push lower-income families into less affluent areas. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the sell-off, citing reforms to reduce social housing waiting lists and increase affordable housing.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases. The cause of his death remains uncertain as an initial examination could not confirm measles as the primary cause. An inquest will be held to allow for further tests. Since the outbreak in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Colfer-Williams had been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and developed a rash shortly after discharge. He visited a GP with the rash but was found dead the next morning. Laboratory tests confirmed measles, but additional tests are needed to determine the exact cause of death. The family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close family members, including his vaccinated daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, according to Cumbria Police. The alleged attack occurred in 2001. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In a National League match, Neil Aspin's Gateshead and Adam Lockwood's Guiseley both maintained their unbeaten streaks, with Gateshead not losing in nine matches and Guiseley in five. Guiseley took an early lead with a goal from Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalized in the second half through Wesley York. The match ended in a 1-1 draw. Key moments included Liam Hogan's block and Jonny Maxted's save for Guiseley, and several substitutions and yellow cards for both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the start of work at a shareholder meeting. The plan was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Lansdown stated that the section 106 agreement will be signed soon, followed by a six-week judicial review period. If no judicial review occurs by March, redevelopment will begin in May to provide certainty to supporters.

Cuadrilla has suspended shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second such event in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining data to determine if operations should resume. The recent tremor, similar to one on April 1, occurred near the Preese Hall site. Fracking involves fracturing underground shale rocks to release gas and has been controversial, particularly regarding environmental impacts. The BGS and Cuadrilla are monitoring the situation and consulting with authorities and experts. The Commons energy select committee supports fracking in the UK with proper regulation. The BGS notes that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause fractures and earthquakes.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpipe player from Liverpool who has been busking in the city center for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud. He was accused of using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner while busking in April 2015, giving the impression he was collecting funds for the campaign. Carpenter denied the charges, stating he was simply busking and had previously performed for the charity. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, confirmed Carpenter had permission to display a banner but not to collect funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0. Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence scored for Ipswich. QPR keeper Alex Smithies' miscue led to Varney's goal. Ipswich, previously struggling to score, dominated the match. QPR, under new manager Ian Holloway, showed little attacking threat and have won only once in their last six away games. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place, while QPR slipped to 15th. Both managers commented on the match, with Mick McCarthy praising his team's performance and Ian Holloway criticizing his team's mental toughness.

Wells, 23, performed well in the T20 Blast last season with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction and praised the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were praised for their leadership. The team's front row and front five made over 70 tackles, contributing to the victory. Coach Churcher highlighted the need for continued improvement, noting that while the performance against Chinnor was emotionally strong, it was not perfect. The Reds' upcoming schedule includes matches against seven lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

The police have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a Bangladeshi citizen, for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town on 14 March. Nazrul was apprehended at a Kolkata railway station following a tip-off that he was returning from Bangladesh, where he had fled after being identified from CCTV footage. This arrest marks the sixth in the case, with police having identified eight suspects, two of whom remain untraced. All previously arrested suspects have implicated Nazrul as the rapist. The incident sparked outrage and protests across India. During the attack, money was stolen from the convent school, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped within the convent. Earlier in May, Milon Sarkar was arrested and described as the gang leader, though his specific role in the crime remains unclear.

The passage discusses an interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, which explains why consumer buying habits change. Factors such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports have influenced the types of items popular among UK consumers. The video also examines changes in the ownership and ranking of major UK brands. It suggests using a non-interactive version for older browsers and provides links to additional information, including details on Chinese ownership, freezing food tips, and a survey ranking the top 20 UK consumer brands.

Two elderly women, one from Sandyhills and another from Stranraer, were scammed by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. The Sandyhills incident occurred on 15 September, and the Stranraer incident happened a week later. The scammers tricked the victims into allowing remote access to their computers, resulting in substantial financial losses. PC Siobhan Pellett warns the public to be cautious of cold calls seeking remote access to computers and emphasizes that banks and reputable businesses never ask for banking details or account numbers over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old former player for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, a third-placed Championship side, after departing from Swinton Lions. As the Scotland assistant coach, he will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell expressed excitement about Duffy's coaching abilities and praised his work under challenging conditions at Swinton. Duffy has been succeeded by his former assistant, Stuart Littler, at Swinton.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. Crewman Chris Page reported that the injured rider had sustained head injuries and was very cold due to being unconscious on wet sand. She received treatment on-site before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to allocate a radio frequency for satellite tracking of aircraft, aiming to improve the current ground-based radar system. This decision follows the disappearance of flight MH370 in 2014, which highlighted weaknesses in global air navigation systems, particularly the 70% of airspace not covered by current tracking methods. The new system will use automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions received by satellites, enabling real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found at 18 living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested in Ohio following a tip received by the FBI on October 30, prompted by issues the teenager faced while applying for college. The FBI collaborated with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to verify the boy's identity. Julian's mother has been informed of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez is additionally charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012 and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected Bobby Hernandez of involvement in Julian's disappearance since 2002, when he claimed to be taking his son to pre-school but instead fled.

Firefighters worked for several days to manage a fire on Duncan Street on 2 March, which led to reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the incident. The fire service noted that the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws. The site, operated by Asset and Land Group, could not be reached for comment and has until 7 August to appeal the EA's decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the premises nine times in the past year, with GMFRS area manager Geoff Harris stating that the site operators had been compliant with fire safety legislation. Concerns raised by the fire service in February about potential fire impacts led to joint visits with EA staff, resulting in EA enforcement action. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, requiring the company to remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, directly linked to the situation in Ukraine, particularly in Crimea where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill aims to allow parts of neighboring states to become new "subjects" of the Russian Federation under certain conditions, such as a referendum or a plea from local leaders, bypassing the need for a treaty. This is argued to be necessary in situations where a state is disintegrating. The second bill seeks to expedite the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing requirements such as a state tax, previous residence in Russia, sufficient funds, and relinquishing Ukrainian citizenship. This bill is framed as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing a perceived threat. Both bills reflect Russia's strategic interest in Ukraine, particularly in Crimea, and its historical precedent of supporting pro-Russian separatists in Georgia.

The passage discusses McLaren's fall from past greatness in Formula 1, focusing on their current struggles and historical successes. Once a dominant force with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, McLaren now aims for the fourth row of the grid and decent points. The team's decline began in 2013 with chassis design issues and has continued with problems related to the Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team has not seen significant success recently. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with notable periods of dominance, such as the 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and the 1998-99 seasons with Mika Hakkinen. The team faced scandals in 2007 and 2009, which further impacted their performance. Ron Dennis, who has been a key figure in McLaren's history, believes the team is on the verge of a comeback, aiming to break Mercedes' hegemony and return to winning ways.

Thomas Baker, also known as Tommy, was found severely injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January. The 44-year-old from Everton had been shot in the head and chest and later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in police custody. Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market before being shot while entering his car. Detectives believe the perpetrators had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene at high speed, traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Authorities urge anyone captured on CCTV near the meat market, even if they think their information is insignificant, to come forward as it could be crucial to the investigation.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online while maintaining a spiritual focus. It mentions:

1. **Everyday Church Online**: A virtual church service that streams recorded sermons and allows global participation via chat. It has attracted users from 61 countries and features a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon.

2. **Guardians of Ancora**: A free-to-play game for children aged 8-11, developed by the Scripture Union, where players act as guardians to rediscover Bible stories and light up a fictional world. Special Christmas quests are included.

3. **Nativity Videos**: Examples of creative nativity videos, such as "The Digital Story of Nativity" by Viral.de, which uses social media updates to tell the story, and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" by the Churches Advertising Network, which transitions a modern couple into Mary and Joseph.

4. **Manga Messiah**: An app and e-book version of Old Testament stories in Manga form, launched by Next Manga, which has been distributed in multiple languages, including to Syrian and Libyan refugees.

5. **Social Media**: The use of platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram by Christian groups to share spiritual messages and connect with their communities during Christmas.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers including Blaenau Gwent council offering around 320 hectares of replacement land. The inquiry has received conflicting expert opinions on whether the circuit would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land is of equal value but is not opposing the development. An ecology report by the developers claims a "net gain" in biodiversity due to plans to enhance other nearby habitats, a claim contested by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a decision after the inquiry, with the final decision resting with Welsh government ministers.

On April 3, Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a report by Novaya Gazeta as an insult to their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, issuing a resolution that included a call for "retribution" against the report's instigators. Novaya Gazeta interpreted this as a call for reprisals against journalists. The paper urged Russian authorities to prevent actions inciting hatred towards journalists. The report, published on April 1, detailed the detention of over 100 people in Chechnya on suspicion of homosexuality, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, stating that detainees were tortured. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, and his spokesman claimed there were no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechen spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, supported the resolution's call for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor, Dmitry Muratov, defended the report and called for dialogue, vowing to continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is assisting those fleeing persecution and may file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia does not prosecute.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has received significant housing benefit payments over the past two years by providing properties for single homeless men, primarily sourced through the charity Fresh Start Housing. Both entities operate legally but have been criticized by a homeless group for their practices. Investing Solutions profits by housing multiple unrelated individuals in one property and claiming housing benefit for each, resulting in a higher total benefit payout than the rent passed to the landlord. The agency and the charity are based in the same building and were both established by Samir Patel. Investing Solutions focuses on housing men over 35, despite legislation allowing this age group to be housed in private rather than shared accommodation. Tenants have reported living in unsuitable conditions, and one tenant, Nigel McCann, described the agency's focus as being on profit rather than people. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over Â£2.1m in the past two years. Matt Downie of Crisis charity criticized the arrangement as a "new low." Samir Patel defended the practices, stating that the majority of rents are passed to private landlords and that Fresh Start Housing is an independent charity. Fresh Start Housing reported housing 788 homeless people since its founding, with 222 in the last year, though it did not disclose how many were housed with Investing Solutions.

In a closely contested game, Great Britain's basketball team, led by Coach Joe Prunty, initially dominated but was ultimately defeated by the Netherlands. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13, with Gordon notably hitting three three-pointers in a row in the third quarter. Despite GB leading 35-24 at one point, the Netherlands took the lead in the fourth quarter, scoring the first 10 points to lead 71-60. Worthy De Jong led the Dutch with 18 points. GB made a late comeback but fell short. Prunty emphasized the importance of effort in every play for the upcoming Eurobasket qualifiers, acknowledging a loss of intensity at times during the match.

Former five-weight world champion Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a boxing match against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC expects McGregor to use 10oz gloves as per rules for fights at 154 lbs, but McGregor and Mayweather prefer 8oz gloves, which offer less hand protection but potentially more punishing punches. Mayweather had announced his intention to use 8oz gloves but had not submitted a waiver. The NAC will debate the glove size on August 16, prioritizing fighter health and safety. McGregor, transitioning from UFC to boxing, has faced criticism but NAC executive director Bob Bennett supports the fight, citing McGregor's boxing skills and physical advantages over Mayweather. Bennett also advised McGregor's team to hire a boxing referee, leading to the appointment of Joe Cortez.

The passage details the closure of the Sunday Post's London office, marking the end of an era for Fleet Street, historically the hub of British journalism. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, the last two journalists working there, reflect on their experiences. Fleet Street, once the center of national newspapers, saw its decline with the move of media operations to other parts of London, driven by technological changes and cost-saving measures. The street, known for its vibrant journalism culture and numerous pubs, has transitioned into commercial spaces. The departure of Sherriff and Smith signifies the final chapter in Fleet Street's storied history as the heart of British journalism.

J.K. Rowling expressed her appreciation for positive comments, noting that they remind her of the prevalence of decent people in the world. She previously mentioned that her personal boundaries were crossed by abusive comments on Twitter. Rowling believes in standing up to bullies and has faced criticism for her political donations, including Â£1m to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and the Labour party in 2008. She revealed that she had been called a traitor for her views and had blocked abusive users, some of whom supported the Scottish National Party (SNP). Despite this, she engaged positively with other SNP supporters, highlighting shared political views. Rowling humorously responded to a suggestion to burn her books by offering to bring marshmallows. The SNP significantly increased its presence in the UK Parliament, winning 56 out of 59 Scottish seats.

The study by University of Edinburgh researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action compared to better-off children committing the same crime. Poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. Girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime compared to those from more affluent households. A history of police trouble is the strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18. Poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Household poverty exacerbates the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors are considered. The study, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, Nuffield Foundation, and Scottish government, has tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998. Despite overall crime rates in Scotland being at a 41-year low, the study highlights that crime remains highly concentrated in the most deprived communities, raising questions about the effectiveness of current inequality-tackling measures.

Mr. Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in the Marian estate in Kilkee in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, from Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody to appear in court next week. Two other men arrested in connection with the incident were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to Det Sgt Padraig Frawley at Ennis District Court, it will be alleged that Walsh and two other individuals entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh. A fight involving weapons ensued, resulting in Mr. Haugh receiving a fatal stab wound to his back. GardaÃ­ recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, along with a bloody knife blade. Mr. Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. The judge noted evidence of tension in the area due to the killing and remanded Walsh in custody until 14 August.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted allegations against Tom Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The tweet, which was deleted within an hour, questioned Elliott's past conduct in the UDR. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan has since admitted the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation" and must post an apology on Twitter. The High Court is yet to determine the compensation amount. The insurance firm indemnifying MLAs has refused to cover Flanagan's compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging in a separate court action. Elliott expressed vindication and disappointment over the lengthy process.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 employees and a history dating back to 1874, has increased its weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet heightened demand. This surge is driven by the successful launch of its branded range in January and growth in its private label business. The company, acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November, sells in various European countries and international markets including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributes the increased production to a rise in orders from both domestic and international clients, expressing optimism about the company's future success.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, sustained serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, admitted hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. The incident occurred as Mrs. Blackburn, a much-loved lollipop lady for 20 years, was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road after the traffic lights turned red. Wright's vehicle failed to stop, hitting Mrs. Blackburn. He expressed deep remorse in court, stating he has thought of nothing else since the accident. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at enhancing anti-submarine warfare capabilities in response to increased Russian submarine activity. The exercise involves a German U-boat, U33, simulating an enemy submarine, while 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, attempt to detect and neutralize it. The exercise highlights the challenges of locating submarines, likened to finding a needle in a haystack, and emphasizes the importance of training given recent Russian submarine sightings near Sweden, Finland, and the UK. The passage also notes the use of advanced technology, such as underwater drones, to aid in detection. Notably, the UK's lack of maritime patrol aircraft is identified as a significant vulnerability, prompting calls for addressing this gap in the upcoming defence and security review. The exercise underscores the need for NATO cooperation in countering the growing threat posed by Russia's advanced submarine fleet.

Since violence erupted in South Sudan in July, 340,000 people have fled to neighboring Uganda, making it the largest refugee influx this year. The United Nations warns that the situation could escalate into genocide and ethnic cleansing. The violence, initially a dispute between the Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, has now targeted Equatorians. Refugees report widespread killing, rape, and ethnic targeting. Uganda has been accommodating, providing land and shelter, but is struggling with the influx, particularly in supplying water. The refugee population includes many children, some of whom have experienced deep trauma. The international community is urged to intervene and pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old professional boxer with a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights, will compete against Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. He transitioned to boxing in 2013 after retiring from football. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the planned construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital as part of a Â£330m investment by the coalition for new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital, costing Â£33m, will replace the outdated current facility built in 1813. It will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The remaining balance of the project will be funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Matron Sue Taylor highlights the current hospital's issues with temperature, maintenance, and its impact on patient well-being. In the past five years, three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and work has begun on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. Dr. Donal Hynes, a local GP, emphasizes the positive impact the new hospital will have on patient care. The new hospital is planned to be built on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with an aim for completion by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city center. He was either in or near a black Mercedes he was driving. Officers arrived at 13:35 GMT and found him with a chest wound. He was taken to Northern General Hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents identified him as a member of a nearby family, who were gathering for a celebration when the shooting occurred. This incident follows several other shootings in Sheffield, though previous incidents were in different areas of the city.

The passage describes the activities of various hacker groups involved in the conflict in Ukraine. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are pro-Ukrainian hackers who have targeted Russian interior ministry servers, police email accounts, and disrupted separatist funding through DDoS attacks. They also hack into public CCTV systems and network printers to monitor troop movements and spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked government websites, electronic billboards, and disrupted vote-counting systems. They claim to have leaked sensitive documents and conversations, including one allegedly admitting to downing Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, publishes leaked Kremlin documents and focuses on Russia's domestic affairs, occasionally covering Ukraine. The group's methods of obtaining material are unclear, and their website is blocked in Russia.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond delivered their farewell speeches before standing down as MSPs ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, reiterated his belief in Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to assume greater governance responsibility. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling unionist politicians' pledges. McNeil, in his final speech, emphasized the importance of accountability, scrutiny, and opposition within the parliament, suggesting there were lessons to be learned from Westminster. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bid farewell, humorously noting she would miss her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She is urging pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care impacts. Her team will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review's goals but expresses disappointment over the lack of provider representation on the advisory panel.

In the year ending June 2016, Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group increased its pre-tax profit by Â£800,000 to Â£3.5 million, despite a Â£1 million drop in turnover to just over Â£100 million. The company noted growth in international sales, particularly in Europe and new markets. Harbro, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, acknowledged the unpredictability of the agricultural outlook and the challenges posed by Brexit, but expressed confidence in its ability to navigate these uncertainties.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. The death is being treated as murder. Detectives are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) and have warned the public not to approach him. McLoughlin is described as white, 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair, and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt. The police are urging anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers, and additional patrols are being conducted in the area to reassure residents.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted the weakening global economy and a delicate juncture in a speech. This follows China's weaker-than-expected trade figures, with exports dropping by a quarter. The IMF is likely to downgrade its global growth forecast from 3.4% when it releases new predictions in April. This situation has ongoing implications for businesses and industries reliant on China's growth.

The council has decided to make the Cowes ferry crossing free until 2 July due to ongoing issues with the new vessel, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. These problems have led to vehicle damage and significant trade loss for local businesses. Council leader Dave Stewart acknowledged the frustrating start and ordered an audit review. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation for local businesses is under discussion and defended the project as a prototype with expected teething problems. The council has authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage and resolved seamanship issues causing groundings.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an agency described as an "international temp agency for beautiful and talented people," faced criticism for its job advertisements that specified physical attributes such as hair color, cup size, and attractiveness. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned these practices as "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women," prompting EHRC's chief executive, Rebecca Hilsenrath, to demand clarification on their hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners and the Fawcett Society also criticized the ads, suggesting they harken back to outdated gender norms. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, emphasizing the importance of looks for their clients. Another controversial ad sought a "sexy female driver" for a high-paying position, which an employment lawyer deemed "clearly unlawful." The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various personal attributes, and the agency's practices were seen as violating these laws. Despite the backlash, Jansen cited specific client requests, including an older gentleman wanting a personal assistant to fit a designed outfit and an Indian businessman hiring women based on physical appearance. Notable clients of Matching Models include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods.

A rare gun crime incident occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly shot two students. Gautami, 18, was shot in the head and another student, Sirisha, suffered severe injuries but is out of danger. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and has been remanded until April 12. India has strict gun control laws, yet firearms are commonly used in settling feuds. This incident recalls a similar 2007 case where a 14-year-old was shot dead by fellow students near Delhi.

The Glaad advocacy group analyzed shows from June 2016 to May 2017 and identified 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's Where We Are on TV study is based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election following controversy over a Â£10.25m loan from the borough council to Northampton Town FC, which he led. The funds, intended for rebuilding Sixfields stadium and developing nearby land, are missing and under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains unfinished. Despite previously intending to stand for re-election, Mackintosh cited the need for new representation for his constituents in his decision.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards and injuring four other teenagers. Oliver was dismissed for policy violations and faces charges of murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. The incident occurred after police responded to reports of underage drinking. Initial claims that the car reversed towards Oliver were disproven by footage showing it driving forward. Oliver faces 5 to 99 years in prison if convicted, which would mark the first conviction of a police officer for murder in Dallas County since 1973. He is currently out on bail.

The passage discusses the decision of Melania Trump and her son Barron to delay moving to the White House until the end of the school year, a choice that has sparked both criticism and support. Historically, only two other First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. The passage notes that Melania's decision aligns with her focus on Barron, as she has previously prioritized his care over public duties. It also highlights that other presidential families have managed similar situations, with some children moving to the White House immediately after their fathers' inaugurations. The role of the First Lady, traditionally ceremonial, has evolved over time with some, like Michelle Obama, taking on more active public roles. The passage suggests that Melania may not fully embrace the traditional First Lady role, with her primary focus being on Barron. It also mentions the possibility of Ivanka Trump taking on some First Lady duties, as seen in past precedents where children or other family members have assisted in the role.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), led by Kate Frame, has been tasked with examining the initial police response to the man's call prior to his death. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaits its conclusions. A Pirc spokesman confirmed that the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) directed Pirc to investigate the police's initial response to the man's call. The findings will be reported to the COPFS.

The passage describes a yellow weather warning issued for strong winds, with gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) expected, particularly west of the mountains. The winds are unusual due to their easterly direction, which may increase their impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is anticipated. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight, a tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey due to the gusts, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain shut for most of Monday for clean-up work.

In the opening game, the Giants initially led through player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. Mike Forney's powerplay goal put the Giants ahead 2-1, only for Andy Bohmback to level again. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored to make it 4-2, before Nottingham's David Ling scored. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Nico Rosberg of Mercedes secured his third consecutive victory, extending his lead in the championship. World champion Lewis Hamilton, also of Mercedes, faced significant challenges, starting from the back, suffering a broken front wing on lap one, and making five pit stops. He now trails Rosberg by 36 points with 18 races remaining. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen managed to recover to fifth place, behind the Red Bulls of Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo. The race was marked by multiple collisions on the first lap, leading to the deployment of the safety car on lap four. Hamilton's race was further complicated by damage to his car from an incident with Sauber's Felipe Nasr, affecting his performance and hindering his ability to close the gap on Rosberg.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent former footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit to advance the discussion on a topic largely ignored in German football. His announcement was widely praised by former teammates, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, and supported by leading figures in German football administration such as Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. Hitzlsperger's coming out is considered a significant step in combating homophobia in football, with Bayern Munich and various public figures, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert, expressing support. This move is hoped to encourage other footballers to come out and contribute to a more open discourse about sexuality in the sport.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship games this season, aiding Brighton's promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. His contract is set to expire, but he hopes to sign a new deal, believing he can help the team stay in the top flight. Brighton secured promotion with a win over Wigan and leads Newcastle by four points, aiming for the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell previously played in the Premier League with several clubs and feels he deserves another opportunity at the top level. He expressed his desire for a new contract, highlighting his significant impact this season.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took an early lead with Jamille Matt scoring after Nathan Delfouneso's assist. Colchester equalized through Kurtis Guthrie's close-range effort following a corner. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made several crucial saves to keep the scores level. The match saw multiple fouls, substitutions, and bookings, including a red card for Colchester's Sean Murray for violent conduct. Key missed opportunities and defensive blocks characterized the game, with both teams having chances to win but ultimately settling for a draw.

The 29-year-old player made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, which resulted in their relegation from League One. The player, Reid, has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He is expected to make his debut for the U's in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester United started their season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday. For the latest football transfers, visit the dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March has led to a greater emphasis on the need for a permanent memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking Â£1.5m to construct this memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff. Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, emphasized the importance of a fitting memorial to honor the contributions and sacrifices of police officers. The memorial, located in Alrewas, Staffordshire, will be dedicated to officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. A brass screen with leaf shapes will be provided to families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. The government, through Home Secretary Amber Rudd, has committed Â£1m towards the Â£4m needed for the project, which is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United leads the table by 15 points with eight games remaining after a 1-0 victory at Sunderland. Manager Ferguson emphasizes focusing on upcoming games rather than past performance, highlighting the team's record of 25 wins in 30 matches. United has accumulated 50 points out of a possible 54 in their last 18 Premier League games and aims to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record from 2005. Ferguson plans changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea. Key players like Wayne Rooney, Ryan Giggs, and Javier Hernandez are expected to be available. Ferguson credits Sunderland for a challenging match and praises his team's determined defending and courage for the win.

Mr. Schmidt, a Google representative, stated that the company paid the legally required amount of UK corporate taxes, totaling Â£10m between 2006 and 2011. He emphasized that tax payment is mandatory and not optional, and any changes in tax amounts would depend on the UK government's tax law adjustments. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed establishing a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, suggesting it could operate in secret to prevent companies from hiding their tax affairs. Google, criticized for routing most of its UK sales through Ireland to minimize UK tax payments, has been a focal point in this debate. European Union leaders recently agreed to combat tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Mr. Schmidt has advocated for corporate taxes to be levied where economic activity and risks are taken, rather than where products are consumed, and called for international tax reform.

The NHS Improvement regulator aims to reduce the NHS's agency staff bill by Â£1bn by the end of the financial year, following a Â£3.6bn expenditure last year. A cap introduced in October has saved Â£600m by limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates for various staff, excluding senior managers. The goal is to lower overall agency staff costs and decrease reliance on them, as they are more expensive due to additional agency fees and employer costs. Despite "promising" progress, NHS trusts are still 10% behind target. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of trust performance on agency spending and collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. Examples of overcharging, such as a surgeon quoted at Â£130 an hour instead of the capped Â£76, highlight the need for further action.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a commercial hub, now symbolizes Ireland's economic downturn post-Celtic Tiger era. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien who runs a family-owned men's clothing shop, have experienced a 30% decline in business but are noticing a recent uptick. O'Brien has diversified his business into childrenswear and dress hire to adapt. Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's investment in water meters, advocating for broadband improvement instead. Robert Troy, a local TD, accuses the government of neglecting the area, noting the lack of foreign direct investment. Conversely, the government highlights the potential employment from Center Parcs' planned tourism development in Ballymahon, pending planning permission. James Bannon, a local Fine Gael TD, is optimistic about the venture, citing the region's natural attractions. Despite these developments, traders like O'Brien call for additional measures, such as free parking, to further stimulate local business. The overall sentiment in the midlands is one of cautious optimism mixed with a call for more supportive actions from the government.

The competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium. Eight teams participate, each facing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Key statistics include leading run-scorers Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249); most sixes by Warner (12) and De Villiers (12); highest scores by De Kock (108), Warner (90*), and Gambhir (90*); and most wickets by McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7). Four England players are involved: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). Fixtures and results are available on BBC Sport, with most matches at 15:30 BST, except noted times.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. These bags, often non-recyclable and discarded after single use, contribute to environmental issues by ending up in landfills and rivers. Starting October, a 5p charge for plastic bags will be implemented in England to promote reuse. This measure, already effective in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where bag usage has decreased, aims to reduce waste and benefit the environment.

On Friday, strong winds in Wales led to significant disruptions, including a school roof being ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts affecting hundreds of homes, train delays, and speed restrictions on major bridges. The highest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries canceled six fast sailings due to adverse weather, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of delays. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Winds eased by Friday evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend resulted in the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about his involvement in an upcoming film, aiming to bring a unique perspective to his role, though specifics were not disclosed. He will collaborate again with director Ryan Coogler, with whom he worked on Creed, and is enthusiastic about working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Nyong'o, an Oscar winner, and Boseman, known for his role as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War, will join Jordan, who previously played Human Torch in Fantastic Four and Nyong'o, who portrayed Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film, Black Panther, is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The passage discusses the restoration and reopening of a theatre founded in 1875, which is part of a larger east wing restoration project at Alexandra Palace. The theatre, which has been unused for decades but retains its original decor and stage machinery, is intended for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios at the eastern end of the Palace will also be repaired and refurbished. The project aims to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination, with the glazed east court becoming a public and exhibition space. Funding for the Â£26.6m refurbishment includes Â£18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund, Â£6.8m from Haringey Council, and a committed Â£1m from Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by summer 2017. If successful in fundraising, the theatre is hoped to reopen in 2018.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner expressed his support for the future success of the team, manager Sam Allardyce, and the fans. Notably, he holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 appearances since 2004. His sole international goal was scored during England's 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, caught fire while they were asleep. Her son David, who was awake on FaceTime with his father, noticed the flames and quickly woke up his mother and sister. The family managed to escape, but their house was destroyed, and their pets did not survive. The fire was caused by rubbish burned in the wood stove, a routine action for Mrs. Smith. The fire alarm failed to activate. The community has supported the family by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith expressed immense pride in her son for his quick actions that saved their lives.

The passage discusses the potential acquisition of a Premier League club by an energy drinks company for Â£200m. Sullivan and Gold, who bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for Â£105m, now own over 85% of the club. Since moving to London Stadium in August, West Ham has been rumored to be a target for takeovers by Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan previously mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but he and Gold plan for ownership to be passed to their children.

The ceremony, distinct from the Oscars, featured fan-voted awards such as best kiss and best shirtless performance, won by Efron. It also served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking best movie, with Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, dedicating his win to Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his kids, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award with his Avengers co-stars. Clips from upcoming films like Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Ultron were showcased.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, praised Smith as a brilliant acquisition and a good fit for the team, providing an additional attacking option. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has initiated a plan to address potholes using Jetpatcher machines due to favorable warm weather conditions. The council aims to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. The exposure, less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), occurred due to inadequate personal protective equipment (PPE) as the area was assumed to be clear. EnQuest took additional precautionary steps post-incident and both companies emphasized their commitment to employee safety. Steve Innes, one of the affected workers, expressed concerns about long-term health effects and criticized EnQuest's duty of care. The Unite union called for greater transparency in safety incidents. The HSE was aware of the incident but did not conduct an investigation as it was not reportable under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer's manager later confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this sculpture, which is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The allegations surfaced during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the museum decided to return the sculpture. The ASI officially requested the return in May. Although there is no conclusive proof the sculpture was stolen from the specified temple, ACM noted the confession of the dealer's manager, Aaron Freedman, regarding dealing in looted Indian antiquities. The sculpture was one of 30 objects ACM bought from the dealer, with none of the others believed to be stolen. The museum plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. No immediate injuries or damage were reported, but phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in Garfagnana. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy, prone to earthquakes, experienced a deadly quake in L'Aquila in 2009, and another significant quake in the same area in May of the previous year. The recent tremor was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" by Alessandro Amato of the INGV. The country is still recovering from the L'Aquila earthquake, which led to the conviction of six scientists and an ex-official for providing falsely reassuring statements about the risk of tremors.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant from Sheffield expressed joy over the growth of fruit in South Yorkshire's climate, despite initial doubts about its suitability. The fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their game until 24 March, originally scheduled for 27 January, to allow for additional testing and polish. The company assures fans that the extra time will enhance the game's quality. As a positive note, online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will feature enhanced graphics, including 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specifications for running the game have been published. Grand Theft Auto V previously set a record as the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its 2013 release.

A 76-year-old artist, Simpson, won the Â£25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. This is his first win, having been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem." The painting, depicting a leper squint from medieval churches, is part of a series Simpson has been working on. He plans to use the prize money for art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked simultaneously early on Thursday. Four masked assailants targeted the Yeni Safak building, while the Yeni Akit offices, located 20km away, also came under attack. No casualties were reported, and firefighters swiftly extinguished the resulting blaze. Police have cordoned off the areas and are investigating the incidents. Both buildings had their windows shattered by gunfire, and numerous spent bullet casings were found at the scenes. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. This incident follows a similar attack in September where pro-government protesters targeted the Hurriyet newspaper, accusing it of misquoting President Erdogan.

The 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, has been acquired by Marcus Bignot's team through a free transfer agreement. He had spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. Formerly a Burton player, he will officially join Bignot's team on 1 January, marking Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsene Wenger, whose contract with his club runs until the summer, has been linked with the England manager's job. Gareth Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce in September, has had mixed results with a win against Malta and a draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's observational skills and experience but emphasized his own focus on his current job. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove his competency for a permanent role. Wenger also discussed Arsenal's plans, mentioning that Hector Bellerin, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, will be offered a new contract, and Aaron Ramsey will miss a couple more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, the Hellier and Hildasay. The RMT union alleged that some crew members were paid less than Â£4 an hour. The new arrangement will transfer contracted services back to operator Serco Northlink from next month. Previously, Seatruck, contracted by Serco Northlink, operated the vessels and argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the non-UK resident crew. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined. Yousaf confirmed that under the new charter, all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds a six-year, Â£243m contract for the Northern Isles route, which includes three ferries and two cargo boats, heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May following an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. Mitchell shouted "yes" and was visibly shaken after the verdict. The trial revealed that Mitchell and Dickie, who had been in a relationship with Samantha, were experiencing a rough patch. On 7 May, Mitchell visited his mother at the park, where they all went to the bar, and Mitchell drank heavily. A confrontation occurred outside the bar, leading to a physical altercation. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and, along with his mother, admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by providing false accounts of the events. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, renowned songwriter known for hits like "Thriller" and "Rock With You" for Michael Jackson, passed away in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. His career included writing for Heatwave, Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin. Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile, began his career in the 1970s with Heatwave and later collaborated with Quincy Jones. He won a Grammy in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. Tributes poured in from artists like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson. His family requested privacy during this time.

Researchers from Swansea University, along with teams from Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities, have discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These geometrical "geoglyphs," concealed by rainforest until modern deforestation, number over 450. Their purpose remains unclear, though they are unlikely to be villages or defensive structures. Instead, they may have been used sporadically for rituals, similar to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr. Neil Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests these geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy, raising questions about their purpose. The research challenges the notion of pristine Amazonian forests before European arrival, indicating human influence over 6,000 years through the spread of various plant species. This suggests ancient "agroforestry" practices, concentrating on valuable trees like palms, which may still influence the biodiversity of some Acre forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian tennis player ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, attributed his subdued behavior during the match to fatigue, citing poor sleep and the challenges of traveling to the Qi Zhong Stadium, which is an hour from Shanghai city centre. This contrasts with his previous behavior at the Shanghai Masters, where he was fined for a foul-mouthed outburst and described the tournament as a "circus."

The passage discusses the call by scientists, charities, and organizations for the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination program to boys, in addition to girls, to protect against head and neck cancers. HPV, a sexually transmitted virus, is already targeted by the vaccine in girls aged 12 and 13 to prevent cervical cancer. The Welsh government is currently awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any decisions. Advocates, including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team, argue that the number of head and neck cancer cases is rising, particularly among younger men who are non-smokers. They urge the government to take a progressive step and vaccinate boys to reduce the global cancer burden caused by HPV, which accounts for 5% of all cancer cases. The vaccination program for girls was introduced in 2008, with 85% of girls in Wales having been vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away after a courageous battle documented on his Facebook page, "Jak's Journey." His mother, Allison, announced his death on the page. Jak attended his school prom briefly before feeling unwell. He was known for his positive attitude and love for Rangers FC, meeting several players. Jak received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy at the prom. His cancer spread, leading doctors to cease further treatment. Jak and his family raised funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. A football match in his honor is planned to raise more funds.

In a closely contested match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda with a goal from Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah in the 89th minute. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside earlier. The win keeps Egypt's hopes alive for the top spot in Group D, setting up a crucial match against Ghana, who have already qualified for the quarter-finals after beating Mali 1-0. Uganda, eliminated from the tournament, will face Mali in their final group game.

Lancashire County Council has selected land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station, following a comparative study by Network Rail. The sports college closed in August, and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus is unused. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed in 1956. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans for two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis highlighted the site's potential for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity. The council will begin the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west without a railway station.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman, a German citizen of Kurdish origin, was found severely injured on a pavement. She was dragged by the neck through several streets and underwent an emergency operation before being transferred to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender and also of Kurdish origin, later surrendered to authorities. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are securing the area and seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School, University of Warwick, and University of Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to receive one. Analyzing 4,600 workers, the research debunked the "reticent female" theory, which suggests women avoid asking for more money. By comparing full-time and part-time male and female workers, the study revealed men are 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they ask. The research also dismissed the notion that women are more hesitant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or conforming to stereotypes. Factors such as employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications were considered. Based on the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, the study suggests there may be an element of discrimination against women. Notably, women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior among younger generations.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location. The money allocated has primarily been used for ground investigations of potential sites, all of which have been discounted due to issues such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After these cemeteries reach capacity, only the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The council remains committed to exploring options despite the challenges. The last increase in burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, scheduled from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content such as videos and band interviews via signs and posters at the site. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan highlights that this new feature enhances the festival experience for on-site visitors and enables global audiences to engage with the festival's atmosphere, access information, purchase tickets, and enjoy a taste of the event from anywhere in the world. The app's content will be updated leading up to and during the festival.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, suffered a severe pulmonary hemorrhage. Despite having shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues and had not exhibited such symptoms during the race. The British Horseracing Authority is committed to understanding the causes of such rare incidents and exploring preventive measures. Many Clouds had previously won notable races, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described by his trainer, Oliver Sherwood, as the "horse of a lifetime."

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl was raped by a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage. Ayrton, now 34 and known as Davina, denied the charge but was remanded into custody by Judge Ian Pearson, likely to be held at a male prison in Winchester. The judge cited substantial risks if she were released on bail. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, spoke about her sexuality during the trial, noting she had not made physical changes or taken medication. She changed her name in 2012. The victim, who had only drunk a can and a half of Foster's, clearly remembered the attack despite her friends being asleep. Ayrton confessed to the attack in 2014 to a care home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

The passage details the recent performance of Serbian tennis player Novak Djokovic. He and his partner lost in the doubles event at the Rio Olympics to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This loss followed Djokovic's elimination from the singles event by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Earlier in the year, Djokovic, the world number one at the time, experienced a surprising third-round defeat at Wimbledon by American Sam Querrey. Despite this setback, Djokovic rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics. The passage also promotes subscribing to the BBC Sport newsletter for updates.

More than 20 competitors from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, will participate in Saturday's chainsaw carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms.
