The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Liverpool has signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa, making him their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. This move follows the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Benteke, a Belgium international, scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since joining from Genk in 2012. He aims to win trophies and reach significant goals with Liverpool. The club struggled for goals last season after selling Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, finishing sixth in the Premier League. Manager Brendan Rodgers has signed Benteke to strengthen the attack, alongside other forwards like Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to injury but returned to score 15 goals, helping Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge both express optimism about Benteke's potential at Anfield.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found no clear evidence of academic improvement from using tablet devices in schools. It surveyed 671 state and independent schools, revealing that tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% having one tablet per pupil. Despite the increasing use of tablets, researchers could not definitively link them to improved academic results. However, head teachers reported positive impacts, and tablets were found to motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. The study also highlighted the rapid integration of technology in young people's lives, with many pupils using devices for social media and videos, even in bed. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The role of technology in schools is expected to grow, with tablets becoming a standard part of education.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images offer a social history of the city and highlight changes in children's lives, including both play and work. The oldest photo, from 1887, shows the Rollo family at a fancy dress ball. Curator Kay Jones selected these images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections, aiming to depict both positive and challenging childhood experiences. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has terminated his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join a National League rival, potentially facing his former club on 18 February. Previously playing for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, Anderson is described by Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson as a leader-type player despite his relatively limited game experience for his age. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, has joined the Gulls pending international clearance. Keating, with prior stints at Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, is characterized by Nicholson as young, raw, but highly motivated. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games, have made these signings to bolster their squad.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs as one of the poorest in South America. It imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Signed into law by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in President Evo Morales's absence, the legislation aims to balance local realities with international treaties. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work, often in hazardous conditions, to support their families. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is reviewing the law to determine if it violates international child labor regulations, noting that children under 15 should not work, though a minimum age of 14 is allowed in developing countries.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress known for roles in films and TV shows like Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, experienced a heart attack, which she referred to as the "widow maker." She initially searched for "women's heart attack symptoms" online after feeling sudden nausea, aches, and a feverish sensation following an incident where she helped a woman in her Nyack village home near New York. Despite not calling emergency services, she took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell emphasized the importance of recognizing symptoms and calling 911 in a blog post on her website, which included a poem titled "my heart attack." She recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed during a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, following a fight with a group of youths attempting to gain entry. He was pronounced dead about an hour after being stabbed in an alleyway at 00:30 GMT. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed at the party and is in stable condition in a north London hospital. Police described the party as well-run with appropriate adult supervision and believe Che was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested and bailed. A 14-year-old boy has been detained on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon. Detectives are seeking witnesses who were near the alleyway during the incident.

Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis system due to poor survival statistics, focusing on cases with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms. The new model includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for alarm symptoms, diagnosis centers for undiagnosed symptoms, and yes-no centers for minor symptoms. This system has improved organization, reduced waiting times, and enhanced survival rates, potentially offering lessons for other countries like Wales.

On 31 March 2014, Powys council was selected to replace the disbanded Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in regulating estate agents in England and Wales. Powys will issue warning and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws, receiving Â£170,000 annually for this service. Complaints about estate agents will initially be directed to local authority trading standards departments, which will refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is believed to have been breached. James Munro from Powys council, leading the new team, hopes this role will demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the roles of healthcare workers, following a Nuffield Trust review that identified examples of nurses substituting for doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The review suggested that with additional training, healthcare workers could take on more responsibilities, which could help address shortages in junior doctor rotas and the increasing patient load on GPs. The Nuffield Trust emphasized the need for reshaping the workforce to focus on managing long-term conditions and highlighted the potential for improving patient care and staff roles. However, unions cautioned against using this approach as a quick solution to NHS problems, stressing the importance of maintaining high-quality training for doctors and securing adequate funding for workforce development. The report's author and NHS Employers' CEO supported the initiative, while medical association leaders emphasized the irreplaceable value of doctors' expertise and the need for proper training and funding.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure, which lasted until 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. Although some bus services have resumed a normal schedule, it is expected to take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the potential impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimated that the lagoon could cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually during migration. TLP refuted these claims, stating they lacked a "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggested a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all fish species. The Â£1.3bn project is seen as a test for larger lagoons, with UK government ministers reviewing its viability. Wales' Environment Secretary expressed support for the scheme but emphasized the need for clarity on the UK government's position. NRW defended its methodology, asserting it was based on the "best available evidence" and had been assessed by independent and technical experts.

The passage announces the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). This body aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The move was announced by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster, who emphasized the importance of the agri-food industry, which supports almost 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, highlighting the need for better coordination of current marketing activities but also noting potential implications for other organizations.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to participate in planting 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, organized by the Woodland Trust. This project, part of a larger initiative to plant millions of native UK trees in memory of WW1 casualties, aims to commemorate the 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict. The four-year project uses the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." The Woodland Trust encourages local people and visitors to contribute to this historical act of tree planting. Director Patrick Cregg highlights the opportunity for personal involvement and the future benefits of wildlife thriving and public relaxation in the wood. The charity will provide saplings and advises volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear. Brackfield Wood is located seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book, described as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story" by judge Alison Graham. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her work on detective VI Warshawski. The awards were presented at Harrogate's annual crime writing festival, with Ann Cleeves noting the strong shortlist. Hilary's winning novel, "Someone Else's Skin," addresses domestic violence and honour crime, featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Paretsky's contribution to crime fiction, including her creation of VI Warshawski and establishment of Sisters In Crime, was highlighted.

Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a finger injury in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed a desire to have Santner back, citing unfinished business. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, will return to Worcestershire following the ICC Trophy in June. He expressed enthusiasm about coming back and making an impact with both bat and ball. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

In 2008, Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev while attempting to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), had briefly returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. Coroner Dr. Elizabeth Earland recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, citing circumstantial but overwhelming evidence. The car had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. Pring's family suspects a staged hit-and-run, motivated by Ziuzina's desire to inherit his assets. They noted her cold behavior and revealed she was a former lap dancer and stripper, not a teacher as initially claimed. Ziuzina sold Pring's belongings and moved his funds shortly after his death. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but reopened it as a murder investigation in 2011, though it remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son, Charlie from Merseyside, requires urgent experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital in America after his last transplant failed. Charlie, who has been ill since the age of three, faced a third relapse in April, leaving no treatment options in the UK. The family was heartbroken when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. An anonymous donor has generously paid for Charlie's treatment, bringing immense relief and gratitude to the family. Charlie's parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, expressed their overwhelming joy and gratitude for the donor's selflessness. The hospital confirmed the donation via email, and Charlie is now cleared to start treatment as soon as possible, with the expected date to be determined next week.

Apple has introduced two-factor authentication for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access, following reports of third-party software being used to steal celebrities' intimate photos. This security measure requires an additional four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering a username and password. Without this code, access to iCloud and purchases from Apple's stores is denied. Users can regain access using a 14-character recovery key if their trusted device is lost. Previously, two-step verification did not apply to iCloud backups, allowing attackers to use Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged Apple's changes as secure but expressed concerns about the recovery key's vulnerability. Security expert Prof Alan Woodward suggested that two-factor authentication should be the default option for companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal where Mark Wright could purchase 20% of Billericay Town FC have not been disclosed yet. According to The Sun, Wright, who was a runner-up on "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, is expected to become a club director. Billericay Town FC currently stands eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, just three points away from a play-off position. Wright has a background in non-league football, having played for clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has recently been acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed his willingness to invest Â£10,000 per week. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mr. Ashley, the owner of Derbyshire company Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter to Mr. Ashley, giving him until 21 March to respond. The letter indicates that Mr. Ashley had invited the committee to a meeting at the company's base but has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered by the committee for a public meeting at Westminster. If Mr. Ashley does not agree to attend one of the offered dates, the committee may seek further action, including support from the House of Commons for a complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request, though the company has previously committed to reviewing worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," which was initiated by the late opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin. The report compiles facts from Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the outbreak of conflict in eastern Ukraine. It argues that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. The report presents evidence, including testimonies from volunteer soldiers and Russian army veterans, asserting that Russian army units and generals were crucial in securing victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. It also details Russian spending on the conflict and the compensation issues faced by the families of dead Russian soldiers. Despite the compelling evidence, the opposition faces challenges in publishing and distributing the report, and questions remain about the public's willingness to accept its findings. The report aims to accuse Putin of directing the war to boost his popularity, though similar past efforts by Nemtsov failed to spark significant protest.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem revealed that the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries. Subsequently, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses tensions between the UK government and the Welsh government regarding the Article 50 letter and the process of Brexit. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration over not being shown the letter before its publication and not being invited to contribute to its drafting, despite the UK government's aim to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's actions, stating that they have been in frequent contact and that the government is acting in the interests of the whole of the UK, with Wales specifically mentioned in the letter. Prime Minister Theresa May mentioned in the letter that powers would be devolved to Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, but the specific powers and accompanying funding remain unclear. Carwyn Jones fears there may be no money to accompany the powers after 2020. The passage also mentions that more details might be revealed in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident involving attacks on PSNI officers in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay over the "mindless attacks" on both the officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page reported that the police were performing their duties when they were attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not expect him to return. Mr. Charney's lawyer claims many statements are false and accuses the company of invading his privacy to gain leverage. The filing includes evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts sent by Mr. Charney to female employees, in response to his defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The company asserts that Mr. Charney violated its sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy, making it unlikely for any board to hire him. American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage details a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app. The teams previously met in Patras, Greece, where Greece, a European title contender, won 92-64. However, three key Greek players will be absent in the upcoming match at the Copper Box in London, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, who is from Stratford, expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and emphasized the importance of the game for GB's preparation for FIBA EuroBasket 2017. This will be GB's only home game before the EuroBasket tournament, which begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the game against Greece, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket. The game timings are 17:30-19:30 BST on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website.

The passage recounts the author's experience during the unveiling of the iPhone by Steve Jobs in 2007. Initially, the author faced difficulty in obtaining the iPhone for a news segment, but eventually secured one from Appleâs marketing chief, Phil Schiller. The author reflects on the initial skepticism and hype surrounding the iPhone, comparing it to the Model T Ford in terms of potential revolutionary impact. Over time, the author acknowledges the iPhone's profound influence on technology and daily life, particularly in photography and mobile connectivity. The passage highlights the transformative effect of the iPhone, which has led to the integration of powerful computing in smartphones used by over two billion people, and has disrupted various industries. The author also notes the continued innovation by companies like Amazon and Google, but credits the iPhone with initiating the mobile connected era.

The passage reports that multiple cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting a toxic substance, confirmed to be antifreeze. The RSPCA is investigating whether these poisonings are accidental or deliberate. Recent cases include seven-month-old Meereen, who died after showing symptoms such as shivering, foaming from the mouth, and attempting to vomit. Her owner, Adria Pearce, is devastated. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock urges residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially during the time of year when antifreeze is commonly used in cars.

The passage discusses the paradoxical situation in Greece where, despite the Syriza government agreeing to further austerity measures and liberalization, there are no protests in the streets. Greece's tourism industry is booming with a significant increase in arrivals. The absence of protests may be due to the anticipation of further revelations about the concessions made by Alexis Tsipras to secure â¬86bn in new credit. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and imposing monetary austerity through bank closures. The new bailout is contingent on Tsipras' ability to offer hope for better economic times. For the bailout to lead to genuine recovery, creditors, particularly Brussels and Berlin, need to show debt forgiveness and avoid triumphalism.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who is being killed off due to a cancer recurrence. Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, accepted the role to support his close friend Windsor and to reunite the Mitchell family for Peggy's farewell. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character since 1990, will return to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, and other significant characters from his past. EastEnders' executive producer, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, highlighted the opportunity to showcase Kemp and McFadden in powerful scenes as the Mitchell brothers face losing their mother.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when informed of her death by Northumbria Police. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice about the situation, believing the police were handling it. Alice's sister, Emma, warned their mother that Dhillon might kill Alice, but her concerns were dismissed. The parents did not fully grasp the severity of the stalking. In response, they established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, aiming to honor Alice's memory and vibrant personality. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The French firm EDF has approved the Â£18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, with one-third of the funding coming from Chinese investors. However, the UK government, under Business Secretary Greg Clark, has announced it will "consider carefully" before backing the project, leading to a delay in signing contracts. Critics warn of environmental damage, escalating costs, and concerns over foreign government involvement. The project, expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity, has faced financial concerns and resignations within EDF. Environmentalists argue it is poor value for money and advocate for more investment in renewable energy. The government's delay has been met with urgency from industry leaders who warn of potential energy supply issues and increased costs if the project is not approved soon.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales includes a field asking for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery. Family lawyers caution that naming a third party often increases conflict and complexity in the divorce process. The Ministry of Justice clarifies that there is no obligation to name this person. Lawyer Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin, both experts in family law, express concerns about the form's potential to encourage naming the third party, despite the guidance stating it is "not normally necessary." Naming the third party involves them in the court case, potentially delaying proceedings and increasing costs if they do not respond. In 2015, adultery was cited in 12,148 out of over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales.

The passage discusses concerns from the forestry industry in Wales about the government's emphasis on environmental aspects over commercial forestry. Britain is the world's third-largest importer of wood, and the industry, valued at over Â£450 million annually, argues that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001. The Welsh government promotes native, broadleaf species and better access for recreation, which conflicts with commercial forestry needs. Confor, representing 200 businesses, highlights the need for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development. The government's Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy aim to encourage woodland planting, but industry representatives like Martin Bishop argue that the current system is too bureaucratic and insufficient in meeting long-term targets. Bishop emphasizes the demand for timber and the potential for increased production if more woodland were available.

A boy was badly injured in Coatbridge after being struck near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street. Emergency crews responded to the incident at approximately 16:40. The boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported to be serious.

During World War II, the Arctic Convoys were missions involving vessels traveling from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. These convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe weather conditions. By May 1945, 104 merchant and 16 military vessels were lost, with thousands of Allied seamen perishing. Winston Churchill described these missions as "the worst journey on earth."

In recognition of their efforts, Russia intended to award the Ushakov Medal to the surviving veterans, but this was initially blocked by the British Foreign Office due to rules prohibiting the acceptance of foreign medals for actions over five years prior. After a campaign, the British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012. An exception was later made, allowing Russian President Vladimir Putin to present the first Ushakov medals during his 2013 visit to London. The Ushakov Medal honors sailors who showed courage in defending Russia.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation report found significant delays and inefficiencies in the community payback scheme, where offenders are required to perform unpaid work as an alternative to imprisonment. Key issues included offenders being let off if they did not attend and a lack of timely enforcement. For instance, one offender completed only 16 hours over 17 months. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the report's 15 recommendations for improvement and stated it was taking action. The scheme, which can require 40 to 300 hours of work for offenses like shoplifting and drug offenses, saw about 70,000 offenders ordered to perform tasks such as garden maintenance and litter-picking in 2014. Inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders. Despite some praise for high-quality work and positive offender feedback, the report emphasized the need for better organization and enforcement to ensure the scheme's effectiveness as both a punishment and a rehabilitation tool.

The passage discusses a newspaper's accusation that a comedian, known for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor, is a hypocrite due to his residence in a luxury home. This accusation is not new and raises questions about how a wealthy individual can authentically represent the interests of the poor. The comedian has previously addressed these criticisms, acknowledging his wealth and fame but emphasizing the need for systemic change and personal transformation. He argues that despite his current wealth, he recognizes the flaws in the capitalist system and continues to advocate for addressing economic disparity and ecological issues. The comedian has not responded to inquiries about potential legal action against the newspaper but has been active on social media regarding the accusations.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, leading to vilification by the scientific community. Despite criticism for his methods and lack of modesty, his work significantly accelerated genomic research. After mapping the human genome, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, culminating in the development of Synthia, detailed in the journal Science. Born in 1946, Venter's early life included surfing and military service in Vietnam, which inspired his medical career and sense of urgency. During his medical training, he excelled in research and pioneered automated gene decoding. His breakthrough in focusing on RNA molecules allowed for rapid gene sequencing. Venter's commercial approach and formation of Celera Genomics challenged traditional scientific methods, leading to both controversy and financial success. In 2006, he established the J Craig Venter Institute to continue his work on synthetic life forms and marine genomics. His synthetic life breakthrough, though controversial, is seen as potentially revolutionary for industrial and environmental applications.

The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust and conducted among about 1,000 parents, revealed that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried foods at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed reported that their children requested to have school-tried foods cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The survey aimed to address concerns raised by a previous Mumsnet survey, which suggested some parents opted for packed lunches due to their children's perceived fussiness. The findings indicate that school meals can help children try new foods and increase dietary variety, with school meals in England now adhering to strict nutritional guidelines. Approximately four in ten primary school children in England eat school lunches, a slightly higher proportion than in secondary schools, while about 46% of children in Scotland eat school lunches. The online survey was conducted between 26 February and 5th March among parents with at least one child aged 4-17 years old.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, is currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 after spending four seasons with Real Madrid. His move to Juventus included an option for Real Madrid to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. Morata, who was previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, has scored three goals for Spain during the tournament. In his two years with Juventus, he scored 27 goals, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He has played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat by Barcelona. Morata, who stands at 6ft 3in, came through the ranks at Real Madrid, making his first-team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson returned to Championship club Forest from Celtic for Â£2.5 million in August 2013. He has been without a team since his release in May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances during his second stint at the City Ground, having previously spent four seasons there before joining Celtic. He also had stints with Preston North End and Notts County. For the latest football transfers, visit the dedicated page.

The British supermarket giant Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm led by billionaire Ron Burkle. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business around Â£80m and may incur a cost of Â£150m for disposing of the Fresh & Easy brand, though part of this may be recouped. Tesco retains the option to buy a stake if Yucaipa succeeds in making the business profitable. Fresh & Easy, which has operated 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007, will see around 50 stores closed as part of the deal. This move follows Tesco's first fall in annual profits in 20 years, reported in April.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it. After briefly considering representing France, this person is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, the passage mentions a special guide on how to get into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, glaciers in the French Alps covered about 375 sq km, which decreased to 275 sq km by the late 2000s, representing a 26% loss over 40 years. This research was presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting. The study, led by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie, assessed around 600 glaciers using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to verify automatic delineation methods. The retreat is more pronounced in the southern sectors due to lower mountain elevations and different climatic conditions. The northern region, including Mont Blanc's La Mer de Glace, shows less retreat. This mirrors findings of glacier retreat in other Alpine sectors across Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, Germany, France, and Italy.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, where a victory would nearly secure their place in the finals. Rachel Evans, a key player, is determined not to miss out on the major competition after previous play-off losses. Iceland, ranked 20th globally, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for group positioning. Scotland is well-placed to qualify automatically as one of the best six group runners-up. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, highlights the importance of having players in top leagues, which enhances the national team's performance. The match is expected to be emotional and pivotal for both teams.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and former computer games reviewer known for his advocacy of Scottish independence and his blog Wings Over Scotland, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint of online harassment from a woman in south London. The allegations involve harassment over a two-year period, specifically related to tweets from his Twitter account. Campbell, who was released on bail, maintains that the tweets in question were not threatening. He criticized the media for using "innuendo" to encourage speculation. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation, and Campbell has been bailed to a date in mid-September.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has proposed replacing the traditional Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a modern, animal-friendly alternativeâa fish named Skegness - A Happy Plaice. Peta argues that the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty, whereas their suggestion would rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, while welcoming all suggestions, expressed doubt about significant support for changing the beloved Jolly Fisherman, who has been a symbol of the resort since 1908. The original poster was commissioned by the Great Northern Railway to promote seaside visits and features the slogan "Skegness is so bracing."

In the match, Georgia initially scored through Vasil Lobzhanidze's try, but Scotland quickly took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson extended Scotland's lead after the break. Lobzhanidze scored his second try for Georgia from a strong scrum, and Hogg added another try for Scotland from a counter-attack. Scotland dominated possession and territory, scoring multiple tries and conversions. Georgia managed to score additional penalties and a second try through their strong scrum, causing Scotland some difficulties. The match ended with Scotland securing a significant victory, reflecting improvements in their game management and approach under head coach Vern Cotter.

Widnes Vikings secured a 38-24 victory over Castleford Tigers, despite a late surge from the Tigers. Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, and two from Lloyd White, along with one each from Joe Mellor and Paddy Flynn, gave Widnes a commanding lead. Castleford's Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick narrowed the gap, but Widnes held on. The win moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, one point ahead of the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti national, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel determined he was no longer a significant threat. He had been held there since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, charges he denies. Al-Odah had contested his detention in the US Supreme Court. Upon release, he returned to Kuwait on a government plane, with his lawyer noting his excitement and joy. The release followed a July determination by Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board that his continued detention was unnecessary for US security. However, al-Odah must spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant rehabilitation center as part of his release terms. His release reduces the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148, and follows the May exchange of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. The US facility, opened in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, has been a target of closure promises by President Barack Obama.

Thousands attended the early morning Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day marks the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One. Additional services were held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The tradition of commemorating Anzac Day in the capital began in 1916 when King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli. The day has since become significant for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. Australian High Commissioner to the UK, Alexander Downer, addressed the crowds, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the courage of the Anzac troops. The Cenotaph parade included members of veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families. The ceremony featured prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The Gallipoli campaign, an eight-month effort to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war, was one of the bloodiest of World War One.

Clarkson, 30, has rejoined Premiership Well and is set to potentially debut for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has primarily been a substitute this term. Clarkson asserts he is match fit and eager to start. With two Scotland caps and nearly 400 senior club appearances, his previous teams include Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, aims to win more games to boost confidence and climb the table. Clarkson emphasizes the importance of each game and the team's goal to return to higher standings.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Initially, there were concerns that the new owners might not maintain the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that productive talks led to guarantees that all current agreements, including the pension scheme, would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, closed in 2004, has an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office assured the continuation of current pension arrangements. Mr. Harley met with Boparan representatives, who expressed their intent to restore Bernard Matthews' profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with the new ferry, which has faced problems since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. The crossing at Cowes will be free until 2 July to acknowledge these problems and gather feedback. Council leader Dave Stewart announced an audit review of the project, describing the start as "frustrating and disappointing." Local businesses, like Angie Booth's Valu-4-U, have suffered significant trade loss and are seeking compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation for businesses is under discussion and defended the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, noting that electrical issues have been fixed and ramp extensions are being manufactured to prevent vehicle damage.

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that while the industry voted heavily for leaving the EU, it may face challenges such as allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a deal. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is seen negatively by the industry, which hopes Brexit will allow the UK to regain control over its waters and become a leading fish exporter. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the industry, which contributes minimally to GDP and employs few people, might be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The report emphasizes the need for continued market access for UK fish exports, mainly to the EU, and suggests that EU states may demand increased access to UK waters in return for zero-tariff sales. The CFP's quotas and scientific advice-based management are recommended to be retained post-Brexit. The industry remains optimistic about Brexit, seeing it as an opportunity for better fisheries management and sustainable practices.

Timothy Geaney admitted to downloading or permitting the downloading of images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He was subjected to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special program for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the professional register due to his conduct being deemed "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher. The panel concluded that his offending behavior, which occurred over a lengthy period, demonstrated a pattern rather than an isolated incident, and there was a strong likelihood of recurrence. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, was prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

Firefighters worked for several days to manage a fire on Duncan Street on 2 March, which led to reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the incident. The fire service noted that the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws. The site, operated by Asset and Land Group, could not be reached for comment and has until 7 August to appeal the decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the premises nine times in the past year. GMFRS raised concerns in February about the potential impact of a fire on residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint visits with EA staff. Consequently, the EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, effective 7 August, barring the company from operating at the site thereafter. The company must still remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria is making efforts to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad cited attacks on shipments by terrorist groups as a reason for the delay. He condemned US Secretary of State John Kerry's criticism of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where numerous civilian casualties have been reported. Mekdad denied targeting civilians and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements. The Syrian government also refuted claims that rebels had seized Aleppo's central prison, though opposition sources reported otherwise. Only about 4% of Syria's declared chemical weapons have been removed so far, raising concerns about the UN-backed plan's schedule. Russia, a key ally, expects Syria to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by 1 March. The OPCW has acknowledged that security concerns have slowed the destruction process.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, achieving their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with his contributions in the field. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, and coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's hard work and improvement. Former players Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott commended England's overall performance, while Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment and a need for improvement. The series is expected to remain competitive, with the third Test scheduled for Edgbaston on 3 August.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care impacts. Her team will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that no provider expert is included on the main advisory panel, missing an opportunity for partnership and full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder and player-manager of Arbroath since 2010, has been appointed as the new manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing at the bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Derek McInnes selected Sheerin following a comprehensive process. Despite Arbroath's desire to retain Sheerin, chairman John Christison understood his wish to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for various Scottish clubs, Ãstersunds in Sweden, and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. He led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion in 2011.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the top choice. The club faces the possibility of relegation, which would make returning to the Premier League challenging. Swansea rose from near bankruptcy to the Premier League by 2011, establishing a reputation for exciting, possession-based football. Curtis, a former player, believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, attributing this to frequent management changes and a dilution of the 'Swansea Way'. Despite these challenges, Curtis believes the current squad can avoid relegation and emphasizes the importance of the club's history to new signings.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, leading to vilification by the scientific community. Despite his controversial methods and self-proclaimed achievements, his work significantly accelerated the genome mapping process. After the human genome's publication, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, culminating in the development of Synthia, detailed in the journal Science. Born in 1946, Venter's early life included a stint in Vietnam that inspired his medical career. His research excellence led him to the US National Institute of Health, where he pioneered automated gene decoding. Venter's breakthrough in focusing on RNA molecules allowed unprecedented gene sequencing rates. Criticized by James Watson, Venter left NIH to establish The Institute for Genomic Research, unveiling the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995. In 1998, he founded Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome, competing with a public project. Both projects published results in 2001, despite Venter's controversial methods. In 2006, he formed the J. Craig Venter Institute to create the first synthetic life form, while also conducting a genetic treasure hunt on his yacht, Sorcerer II. Venter's synthetic life breakthrough, though controversial, aims to revolutionize industry by producing cells that could reduce oil dependency and capture carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The report, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, highlights that only 200,000 out of 520,000 annual apprenticeships in England are rated at level three (equivalent to A-level), and only 61,000 are for young people. In contrast, Germany offers 570,000 apprenticeships for young people, 90% of which are equivalent to A-levels. The report calls for the creation of up to 300,000 new apprenticeships annually, with the majority at level three for at least three years, to improve job prospects and economic competitiveness. It criticizes England's vocational system for being complicated and undervalued, and urges reforms to make apprenticeships more rigorous and respected. The Department for Education acknowledges the need for reform and has already implemented some changes, with plans for further reforms to be announced.

The Briton, Storey, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, aged 37, expressed relief at the win and is aiming for further Paralympic success at the upcoming Games in Rio de Janeiro. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. Storey has won 21 world titles and four golds at the 2012 London Games. She started her career in swimming, winning six Paralympic medals in 1992, before transitioning to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to their failure to meet payment deadlines for football creditors, totaling Â£148,000. The club's financial struggles, exacerbated by falling attendances since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, led to multiple deadline extensions being granted but ultimately not met. The expulsion follows a dramatic final season where Hereford narrowly avoided relegation. Chester, who were originally relegated, have been reinstated in their place. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for Â£1 and clear debts, but this was not accepted. The club still owes over Â£70,000 to HM Revenue and Customs.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 appearances, starting in 2004. His sole international goal was scored during England's 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. In his statement, Milner expressed his wish for success for Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it globally for about 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. Colleagues and friends remember him for his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling by his parents due to difficulties coping. His family sought a place in a special school but faced delays as all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. The boy's mother expressed concern over his isolation and the impact on his well-being. Recently, an extra classroom assistant was hired at a local special school, offering hope for his enrollment soon. However, the mother worries about other families facing similar issues due to the over-subscribed special needs school system. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability closer to children's residences, with efforts ongoing since 2016.

The Newport Gwent Dragons are facing a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who view Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County, who have a lease to use the ground until 2023, expect their contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on May 9. Newport County secured a 10-year lease in 2013 after promotion to the Football League. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey assures that both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. On the field, County leads League Two by two points with two games left, aiming to secure survival under caretaker manager Mike Flynn. Relegation would be a significant blow to the club and the city of Newport.

Last weekend, Sierra Leone was declared free of the Ebola virus, which had killed nearly 4,000 people over 18 months. The passage recounts the experiences of an individual who, at 15, was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the civil war (1991-2002), trained to use weapons, and subjected to brutal initiation rituals. After escaping and living a troubled life, he was inspired by a preacher, Richard Cole, to rebuild his life and contribute to the nation. During the Ebola crisis in 2014, he and others transformed their clinic to handle suspected Ebola cases, focusing on education, community support, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit. Despite initial resistance and fear, their efforts saved many lives. The individual now sees himself as a changed person, committed to investing in young people for a better future.

A collection of about 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, originally at risk of being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, will remain intact and on display. A successful public fundraising campaign, led by The Art Fund, achieved its target in a month. The collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and then loaned to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Wedgwood Museum had inherited the pension debt of Waterford Wedgwood plc after its collapse in 2009, leading to its own administration in 2010. A high court ruling in 2011 allowed the collection to be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund, but the recent fundraising efforts prevented this. The collection's preservation is considered vital for Staffordshire's cultural heritage and Britain's national identity.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal where Wright could purchase 20% of the club have not been disclosed yet. According to The Sun, the 30-year-old is expected to become a club director. Billericay Town, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points away from a play-off position. Wright, known for being a runner-up in "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, has a background in non-league football, having played for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has recently been acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed comfort in investing Â£10,000 weekly. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35, in early March.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took an early lead with Jamille Matt scoring from a pinpoint chip by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized through Kurtis Guthrie after a corner. Blackpool's Sam Slocombe made crucial saves throughout, denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi. Despite several chances for both sides, including a missed header by Tom Aldred, the score remained level. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle. Key moments included multiple fouls, injuries, and substitutions, but no further goals were scored.

The passage discusses the proposed redevelopment of the disused Fawley Power Station, which closed in 2013 after 40 years of operation. Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the 300-acre site into a "merchant city" development, featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The centerpiece of this Â£1bn project is the 198-meter-high chimney, which will be repurposed as a major attraction, making it the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The power station, commissioned in 1971, was a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired facility capable of powering one million homes, with 1,100 miles of cable laid within. The developers aim to start building in 2018, pending outline planning permission.

At the Hong Kong championships, Jonothan Latham secured Great Britain's second medal by winning bronze in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham overtook several competitors in a final sprint, narrowly missing silver and gold, which were won by Adrian Teklinski of Poland and Lucass Liss of Germany, respectively. In the men's team pursuit, GB was edged out for bronze by Italy. Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and the women's team pursuit squad, including Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker, finished fifth and did not compete for a medal. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

Ross Kemp is briefly returning to EastEnders for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, accepted the role to support his close friend Barbara. Peggy Mitchell, who returned to the show after leaving in 2010, is set to die from cancer in upcoming emotional scenes. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character since 1990, will reunite with his brother Phil (played by Steve McFadden) and other family members for the storyline. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the significance of the Mitchell brothers coming together to face their mother's death.

Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession as Spurs, in second place, underperformed at Anfield. Manager Pochettino criticized the team's lack of desire and readiness to fight for the Premier League, especially after a poor start to the game. Chelsea could extend their lead at the top if they win against Burnley. Spurs have struggled on the road, winning only twice since September 24, including losses to top teams. In their last 17 away meetings with top-six rivals, they have won just once. Pochettino emphasized the need to cope with pressure to challenge for the league. Former midfielder Danny Murphy noted Spurs' unusual defensive setup and lack of pace away from home, suggesting they need to improve quickly.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential poll last month, saw its decline reinforced by these results. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna but retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with most northern states and Lagos going to the APC. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could impact oil revenue. The elections, though marred by violence in some areas, were more peaceful than previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under new leadership.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, introduces an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content like videos and band interviews via signs and posters. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as an enhancement for festival enjoyment and global interaction, with updates providing real-time access to information, interviews, and ticket purchases.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns are addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools reported feeling undermined by parents during an Ofsted inspection. The Department for Education issued letters to the schools' trusts, outlining actions required by 4 July, including ending segregation and ensuring a balanced curriculum. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw described a "culture of fear and intimidation" in Birmingham schools. Parents criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, is accused of gross negligence manslaughter for allegedly failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test, which the prosecution claims was far below the expected standard and "criminal." The failure to refer Vinnie for further investigation is central to the prosecution's case. A build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain increased pressure in his skull, leading to his death. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death was preventable if Ms. Rose had performed her duties properly. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he found through an adult website and filming them. He also sent a sexually explicit video to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014. Weatherhogg denied the charges but was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court. Due to the severity of the offenses, the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. He was placed on the sex offenders register and assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending. The judge emphasized the need for a sentence that reflects society's abhorrence of such conduct.

In the first T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with contributions from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and William Porterfield (39). Afghanistan successfully chased the target with 171-4, aided by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed early for a duck. Afghanistan's opening partnership of Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27) set a strong foundation. Amir Hamza was the top bowler for Afghanistan with 2-23. Ireland's Porterfield noted they fell short of their target score and struggled with bowling execution. The absence of Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was a setback for Ireland, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs.

Barcelona, the Spanish football champions, have made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential interpretations of their fiscal obligations in the signing of Neymar. The club maintains they did not commit any offence and that the original tax payment was in line with their obligations. Neymar's total cost to the club, including various fees, is Â£106.8 million. This move follows accusations of misappropriation of funds against former president Sandro Rosell, who resigned and is under investigation, though he denies any wrongdoing. A judge in Spain has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

On 15 September, the bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao. UK Metropolitan Police officers collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun. The UK detectives have completed their review of the investigation and are returning to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if convicted. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA verification and allegations of mistreatment. The UK police visit followed an agreement between Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha and Mr. Cameron. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA found on Witheridge matched samples from the suspects.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, where a victory would nearly secure their place in the finals. Rachel Evans, a key player, is determined not to miss out on another major competition after previous play-off losses. Iceland, ranked 20th globally, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for group positioning. Evans, a Bayern Munich forward, emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals and the emotional impact it would have. Scotland is well-positioned to qualify automatically as one of the best six runners-up. Evans highlights the benefits of having players in top leagues, which enhances the national team's performance. The squad includes players from various top leagues, contributing to the team's competitiveness.

Apple has introduced two-factor authentication for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access, following reports of third-party software being used to steal celebrities' intimate photos. This security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password on a new device. Without this code, users are denied access to iCloud and cannot make purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. Users can regain access using a 14-character recovery key if their trusted device is lost or stolen, but this key must be kept safe. Previously, two-step verification was available but not enforced for iCloud backups, allowing attackers to use Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download data. Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged Apple's changes as secure but expressed concerns about the recovery key's vulnerability. Security expert Prof Alan Woodward suggested that two-factor authentication should be the default option for all users, not just an opt-in feature. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

In the recent election, UKIP, which won, spent Â£2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent Â£2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent Â£1,580,575 and lost most of their MEPs. Labour, which came second, spent Â£1,027,339. The campaign period was from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending equates to 68p per vote, Labour's to 26p, the Conservatives' to 79p, and the Liberal Democrats' to Â£1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent Â£534,249, equating to 43p per vote. Including the SNP's Â£267,372, the six highest-spending parties collectively spent Â£9,347,087. All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join a National League rival, potentially facing his former club on 18 February. Anderson, with experience at Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, is described by Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson as a leader. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, has joined subject to international clearance, having played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Nicholson notes Keating's youth and hunger to prove himself. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone with one win in their last six games, aim to strengthen their squad with these additions.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. He was treated by veterinary staff but pronounced dead due to a severe pulmonary hemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he had no significant underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, including overheating and wobbling, but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms in this race. He had a notable racing history, including wins in the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime." The incident raises questions about potential links between his past overheating condition and his death, though the report concludes he died from a rare racetrack hemorrhage.

In the Scottish Parliament, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond delivered their farewell speeches before standing down as MSPs ahead of the May 5 election. Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to assume greater governance responsibility. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling unionist politicians' pledges. McNeil, in his final speech, highlighted the importance of accountability, scrutiny, and opposition within the parliament, suggesting there were lessons to be learned from Westminster's committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bid farewell, joking about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The upcoming film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast" features an Oscar-winning cast: Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Emma Thompson will voice Mrs. Potts, and Kevin Kline will play Maurice. Directed by Bill Condon, the movie is set to release on 17 March 2017 and begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding potential charges in the Hillsborough disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. The disaster, which occurred on 15 April 1989 during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest, resulted in the unlawful deaths of 96 football fans. New inquests concluded last year that the fans were unlawfully killed. Evidence files relating to 23 suspects have been referred to the CPS, with 15 files from the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and eight from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, anticipate the decisions with mixed emotions, emphasizing their long struggle for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, being thrown over the wall. A former inmate described the prison as notorious for being flooded with such contraband, and claimed drones were used, though the Ministry of Justice denied evidence of drones at this site. The Ministry acknowledged the hard work of staff in preventing contraband but recognized the need for further action. The Justice Secretary has been asked to explore ways to better equip prisons to handle this issue. A local resident reported witnessing such incidents multiple times and expressed concern, leading the prison to organize a meeting for nearby residents on how to handle such situations. Smuggling packages over prison walls is now a criminal offense punishable by up to two years in jail.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, sustained serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red traffic light. He admits hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, a mother-of-three and a lollipop lady for 20 years, is now in residential care. During the trial at Luton Crown Court, Wright expressed deep remorse, acknowledging the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. Despite finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, she is unable to attend the April event as her exams are scheduled for May. Muir expresses her disappointment but emphasizes the importance of completing her degree. She is optimistic about her future in athletics, including potential participation in the World Indoor Championships in March and multiple Olympics. Muir achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations in a three-acre woodland area near the River Liffey, began in response to new leads. This search is expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed Deely's case, enhancing CCTV footage that shows him talking to a man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street. The man in black is believed to have followed Deely on Haddington Road shortly after. Despite releasing the footage and appealing for the man to come forward, he remains unidentified. GardaÃ­ have renewed their appeal for information.

Juan Martin del Potro, currently ranked 165th after a two-year injury hiatus, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a thrilling match at Wimbledon, winning 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. Del Potro, a former US Open champion and world number four, is playing in his first Grand Slam since 2014 following three wrist operations. He expressed joy and a renewed sense of purpose after the victory. Del Potro will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. In other matches, Nick Kyrgios overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match, and Feliciano Lopez fought back from two sets down to defeat Fabio Fognini. Routine victories were also secured by Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 tournament, but avoided disqualification after apologizing. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 AFCON qualifying draw but was allowed to participate after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) overturned the ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 AFCON due to Ebola fears, leading to Equatorial Guinea stepping in as host. Tunisia's dispute with Caf arose from a controversial penalty awarded during their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in 2015, which Tunisia lost.
